- mattjj commented on 2022-04-20T16:46:04Z: I kinda like the way it is written now, but IIUC @YouJiacheng may be observing that using the `in` syntax is extra clear for testing membership.

I'm not necessarily advocating for this but we could make a `jax.util.SetById` like

```python
class SetById:
  _elts: Set
  def __init__(self, elts):
    self._elts = elts
  def __contains__(self, elt):
    return any(elt is e for e in self._elts)
```

(We could also back it by a set of object id integers if we wanted.)

I'm not sure but I think this pattern has come up a couple times (needing to test membership by id), so it could make sense to have a utility class like this.

All that said, by default I probably wouldn't change anything unless/until we notice reusing this kind of idiom in a few different places...
- YouJiacheng commented on 2022-04-20T16:46:38Z: FYI, the performance difference is negligible
```python
import numpy as np
_weak_types = [int, float, complex]
id_set = set(id(t) for t in _weak_types)
from timeit import timeit
print(timeit('any(np.float32 is t for t in _weak_types)', globals=globals(), number=1000000)) # 0.480
print(timeit('id(np.float32) in id_set', globals=globals(), number=1000000)) # 0.126
print(timeit('any(int is t for t in _weak_types)', globals=globals(), number=1000000)) # 0.375
print(timeit('id(int) in id_set', globals=globals(), number=1000000)) # 0.116
```
only 0.2~0.3 μs. The explicity is more important.

When a type hint contains names that have not been defined yet, that definition may be expressed as a string literal, to be resolved later.

The string literal should contain a valid Python expression (i.e., compile(lit, '', 'eval') should be a valid code object) and it should evaluate without errors once the module has been fully loaded. Pull Request 7859 titled 'Change the default matmul precision in JAX to highest precision.' was created by copybara-service[bot] (Bot). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- patrickvonplaten commented on 2022-02-22T20:01:00Z: Big +1 from the Hugging Face team for this PR. We're constantly running into problems with the default fast-speed low precision TPU default as shown here for example: https://github.com/huggingface/transformers/issues/15754 . The example there shows how quickly hidden states diverge from the original PyTorch implementation of one of the most important speech recognition models (Wav2Vec2) which is very similar to BERT.
- hawkinsp commented on 2022-02-22T20:06:02Z: I want to note that this PR has stalled because we haven't been able to come to agreement about what a best default is. No choice makes everyone happy.

Would the `default_matmul_precision` config option solve your problem?

It can be set globally or as a decorator, e.g.
```
@jax.default_matmul_precision("float32")
def f(...): ...
```
- mattjj commented on 2022-02-22T22:26:16Z: @patrickvonplaten thanks so much for that input. The feedback is really helpful, especially from HuggingFace.
- patrickvonplaten commented on 2022-02-23T11:50:54Z: Thanks a lot for your feedback @hawkinsp and @mattjj ! The `default_matmul_precision`: `JAX_DEFAULT_MATMUL_PRECISION=float32` global flag as @mattjj nicely explains [here](https://github.com/google/jax/pull/6143) nicely solves the problem, but you have to know that it exists **and** you have to know that the default precision is `bf16` for TPU. For our community and even people within Hugging Face, this is not intuitive really. 

To give a bit more background, most of our Transformers users use PyTorch. More and more start looking into Flax/JAX + TPU now though because:
- performance
- Compared to PyTorch, there are arguably less gnarly bugs, the API is more intuitive for multi-TPU or multi-GPU settings of its performance and especially because multi-device settings and model/data parallelism works very well in is very intuitive (arguably much more than it is for PyTorch)

Now IMO the reason because it's not intuitive is because:

1. People come from PyTorch using GPU. They associate Flax/JAX with TPU and kind of transfer there PyTorch/GPU knowledge to the Flax/JAX TPU use case. So training scripts are run and the gradients explodes, loss is unstable -> if you don't know the difference between GPU/TPU and float32/bf16/fp16 it's not very straight-forward to find answers why the loss is unstable. I do think lots of people start using TPU expect that the precision is as high as possible and the code is optimized only when defined so by the user. E.g. `bfloat16` is not the default in PyTorch GPU, people have to define this themselves.

2. The global flag `JAX_DEFAULT_MATMUL_PRECISION` is great, but it's pretty hard to find out about this, e.g. when googling. For comparison if I google  "set GPU device for PyTorch", it's trivial to find the `CUDA_VISIBLE_DEVICES` flag. However if I google "Set precision for JAX TPU", I'm not finding the "JAX_DEFAULT_MATMUL_PRECISION" flag at all. I quickly see [this](https://github.com/google/jax/issues/1856) issue and https://cloud.google.com/tpu/docs/jax-quickstart-tpu-vm, but no where is this flag mentioned. I think there are people who at some point come to the conclusion that they have to specif icy the precision manually at every https://flax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_autosummary/flax.linen.Dense.html# module because they just don't know that this Flag exists. So somehow making this flag more prominent in the docs/issues is **really** important I think.
- patrickvonplaten commented on 2022-02-23T11:54:19Z: Also pinging some community contributors here who frequently use JAX in combination with Flax on TPU - to give some feedback: @borisdayma @stefan-it
- borisdayma commented on 2022-02-23T15:53:29Z: I was not aware of matmul precision flag, nor its default and whether it differs from Pytorch.
I've been using the `dtype` argument from `flax.linen` modules, not sure if it's related…
- evanatyourservice commented on 2022-04-13T00:46:59Z: Hello! I've been following this discussion off and on and actually ran into this problem again today so I figured I'd add my +1.

My muzero implementation kept failing the past couple days and even though I knew about default_matmul_precision and its default being bfloat16, it still took me forever to figure out that this was the problem. It ended up needing tensorfloat32 or higher. I also ran into this problem a while ago training wavenets, which also needed tensorfloat32 or higher. It's common for folks to say that there is no difference between bfloat16 and float32, but in my experiments there has been a huge difference, and my belief that there was not much difference between the two only led to wasted time.

My opinion would be to at least set tensorfloat32 as the default, as this seems to be a nice compromise between speed and precision. If someone really wanted to eek more out of jax one way or another, either more speed or more precision, the other options could be found in the docs and implemented. Full float32 wouldn't be a bad choice either, as this would drastically lessen the chances of a problem being caused by the default precision. It may also help people to mention in the docs that there is in fact a difference between the precisions and that they can affect model performance. The TF bfloat16 docs only mention positives and say it is a drop-in replacement for float32, but as I gain experience with TPUs I believe this is simply flat out wrong.

Pull Request 6758 titled 'Simplify `unzip2` and `unzip3` utility functions' was created by lgeiger (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2021-05-14T21:28:08Z: I think the test failures point to the reason these utilities are defined the way they are: for empty iterators, `unzip2` and `unzip3` always return tuples of length 2 and 3, respectively. `zip(*x)` returns an empty tuple when `x` is empty.

They could maybe be written more succinctly with something like:
```python
def unzip2(args):
  return tuple(zip(*args)) or ((), ())
```
- lgeiger commented on 2021-05-14T21:42:30Z: > for empty iterators, unzip2 and unzip3 always return tuples of length 2 and 3, respectively. zip(*x) returns an empty tuple when x is empty.

Good point, sorry for exercising CI instead of checking this locally. I changed the PR to handle empty iterators correctly.
- mattjj commented on 2021-05-14T21:49:40Z: Thanks for looking for ways to improve JAX internals!

But I think there's some misunderstanding here: we're well aware of how `zip*` can be used, but `unzip2` and `unzip3` are specialized for good reasons, including whether they raise clear errors or fail silently:

```python
In [1]: from jax._src.util import unzip2

In [2]: def new_unzip2(xys):
   ...:     return tuple(zip(*xys)) or ((), ())
   ...:

In [3]: unzip2([(1, 2), (3,)])
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-3-40905abf4923> in <module>
----> 1 unzip2([(1, 2), (3,)])

~/packages/jax/jax/_src/util.py in unzip2(xys)
     44   xs = []
     45   ys = []
---> 46   for x, y in xys:
     47     xs.append(x)
     48     ys.append(y)

ValueError: not enough values to unpack (expected 2, got 1)

In [4]: new_unzip2([(1, 2), (3,)])
Out[4]: ((1, 3),)
```

You wouldn't believe how many times that's saved us!

So in other words, having `unzip2` and `unzip3` with explicit, specialized implementations is quite intentional.

In any case, thanks again for looking for ways to improve! This isn't a spot to improve, but I'm sure there are many others.

Comments:
- jekbradbury commented on 2021-02-04T10:18:53Z: Still need to put name handling in the collective abstract evals that @apaszke recently added.
- jekbradbury commented on 2021-02-05T19:47:25Z: This should be ready for review now.

The reason I think it's okay to assume commutativity (and break multiply-batched while_loop) is that I think we can fix the while_loop issue before we start to rely on named avals outside xmap (and implementing the non-commutativity-assuming approach was getting pretty hairy).
- froystig commented on 2021-02-09T01:49:28Z: Some context on this change, since it includes a major conceptual step in the "avals with names" effort:

Our overall goal in this sequence of changes is to introduce "mapped" axes explicitly into the internal type system. We represent these with names, distinct from "positional" axes, for a variety of reasons that I won't review here. Why change the type system? One of several reasons is to track the common action of our parallel primitives, independent of how their operation grounds out under any specific map (`pmap`, `vmap`, `xmap`, etc.).

This change takes the first step to that end, by making abstract evaluation aware of named axes. Now we need every abstract eval rule to propagate them. We can think of this as pulling an "abstract" version of each primitive's batching rule into its abstract eval rule. @jekbradbury actually proposes doing this automatically: partially evaluating the batching rules to extract abstract evaluations. We're not sure that this is necessary, nor that it cover primitives like `cond` that have non-default abstract evaluation rules, so we'll need to follow up on that either in this change or soon after it.

Pull Request 3736 titled 'Curry jit, grad, value_and_grad and vmap.' was created by BuddenD (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- shoyer commented on 2020-07-23T18:57:49Z: The alternative to adding a toolz dependency would be to write our own helper function, e.g., a decorator that produces something like:
```python
def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
  if args or 'fun' in kwargs:
    return jit(*args, **kwargs)
  else:
    if args:
      raise ValueError("can't use positional arguments when currying")
    return partial(jit, **kwargs)
```





- mattjj commented on 2020-07-24T17:50:52Z: Thanks for proposing and prototyping this! Recording my thoughts here for posterity, though we discussed more in our chat rooms. Not everyone agrees with the reasoning or conclusion here!

I don't think we should merge this. My primary concern is that there are unforeseen edge cases that will end up harming usability on net. Once we merge a new api that users start relying on, if edge cases later emerge it may be difficult or impossible to revise our decision and remove it. It's possible that there are _no edge cases at all_ to this convenience layer, but the `tools.curry` logic [looks tricky enough](https://github.com/pytoolz/toolz/blob/ea3ba0d60a33b256c8b2a7be43aff926992ffcdb/toolz/functoolz.py#L300-L335) that it's not easy for me to make that claim without deeper investigation. To be confident, I'd want to thoroughly understand the `toolz.curry` logic, and still probably brainstorm and write tests for all the evil edge cases I can think up. That would take time, and I don't think the potential upside of this convenience layer justifies that kind of time investment given our other priorities.

A distant secondary concern is performance. `jit` dispatch time isn't good now, but because it's relatively simple we know how to make it fast, and we've already started working on that. I don't want to add another wrapper from an external library to that path now, since it's another potential blocker to fast dispatch.

The current solution to the issue at hand here, with `@partial(jit, ...)`, is simple and predictable. It may be unfamiliar at first, but it's easy to learn and once learned it's easy to understand and predict its behavior. Moreover, any user who wants a curried version can get it as simple as:

```python
import toolz
from jax import jit

jit = tools.curry(jit)
```

That is, we don't need to bundle these things together for users. They can use composition instead.

While I don't think we should merge this, I appreciate the time you put into making a concrete proposal we could debate. Without it, we wouldn't have been able to weigh alternatives! Investigating this carefully made JAX better.

Comments:
- levskaya commented on 2020-05-13T06:52:02Z: @j-towns is your gradient error showing up for real eigensystems or complex?  given that it's nonsymm `eig` could it be the latter?  i.e. are you doing a simple elementwise comparison of complex eigenvectors?  The phase freedom of complex entries makes numeric eigenvector gradient checking a bit more complicated than just using `check_grads`.
- j-towns commented on 2020-05-13T09:48:11Z: Yeah indeed. I've dug into the implementation details of eig and it seems the 'phase freedom' is actually constrained by setting the largest element (in absolute value) of each eigenvector to be real, thus the output of `(np|jnp).linalg.eig` is actually uniquely determined.

However it's questionable whether we should implement gradients that cater to that specific choice of constraint, since it's pretty arbitrary, and it feels like users shouldn't be depending on it in their code...

Some discussion on this towards the bottom of #2748. I'm not sure what the right answer is for these grads atm.

Pull Request 2574 titled 'Add NFE counting for odeint' was created by jacobjinkelly (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- shoyer commented on 2020-04-01T22:50:41Z: Very nice, we definitely need support for this! I want the same thing for iterative linear solvers like conjugate gradients.

If I understand correctly, you are putting the evaluation counter in the cotangents? Is is possible to get this information out if you're using `odeint` as part of a larger function on which you're calling `grad`? It feels like we might need a more comprehensive solution here. Right now my guess is that this wouldn't work.

I also wonder if we ever might want to return other metadata from the solver, like the chosen timesteps. Some of these fields could have a float dtype, but they won't have valid derivatives defined -- at least that could be computed without differentiating through the solver itself, which the entire point of these custom gradient rules is to avoid. It seems like we really should have some way of indicating such terms are "non-differentiable".
- jacobjinkelly commented on 2020-04-02T02:58:14Z: Yes, I'm putting the evaluation counter in the cotangents. To get the information out of the grad of a larger function (call it `f`) using `odeint`, you must call `_odeint_wrapper` instead and thread a dummy argument through `f` and `_odeint_wrapper` . If you take grad wrt that dummy argument you get the auxiliary information. Essentially I'm putting auxiliary information in place of a derivative wrt the dummy argument. You can see in an example in `pend_get_nfe` in the PR.

I totally agree that this solution won't work in general, and what we really need is a general option for a vjp to return auxiliary information which is separate from the auxiliary information returns with the primals on the forward pass.
- samuela commented on 2020-04-24T18:14:58Z: This PR makes me wonder: What is the idiomatic approach to handling auxiliary data/results in JAX, both in terms of primal functions and their vjp's? 

I'm in roughly the same boat as @jacobjinkelly... I also need to get auxiliary results out of `odeint`, but it's not clear what the right approach to doing so is.
- samuela commented on 2020-04-24T21:37:54Z: Getting auxiliary info out of vjps seems like the messier of the two problems. Like how would it work with `value_and_grad`? And what about higher-order gradients etc etc...
- mattjj commented on 2020-04-24T22:15:24Z: I am wondering the same, @samuela. Thoughts welcome, though @jekbradbury has led an internal group brainstorming about this (e.g. including Flax and Haiku folks) and it's very tricky.
- samuela commented on 2020-04-24T22:38:57Z: @mattjj I really haven't thought this through yet! But this seems like the right use case for something like algebraic effects: Code can be instrumented by adding effects for the values of interest and then it's up to client code to register effect handlers for the things they care about. This way effects do not get in the way of function return types and users can be selective in the information they want, and how it should be processed. Presumably some people just want to log debug info, others may want to record it, etc.

The challenge I foresee in such a system would be getting this to play nicely with XLA which presents a bit of a challenge. XLA has only limited support for side effects. Custom calls are one option but they'd be incredibly slow if you have to jump back out into Python in the middle of a hot loop. Perhaps there could be some way to trace effects and their handlers? XLA is great for speedy numerical code, but it does makes this all a little tricky.
- shoyer commented on 2020-04-24T23:03:14Z: > The challenge I foresee in such a system would be getting this to play nicely with XLA which presents a bit of a challenge. XLA has only limited support for side effects. Custom calls are one option but they'd be incredibly slow if you have to jump back out into Python in the middle of a hot loop. Perhaps there could be some way to trace effects and their handlers? XLA is great for speedy numerical code, but it does makes this all a little tricky.

I think a tracing based approach that rewrites code so it looks functionally pure from the prospective of XLA here is _probably_ the right approach. This is what @jekbradbury used in https://github.com/google/jax/pull/1803 and I think @sschoenholz has explored some prototypes along the same lines as well.

- jacobjinkelly commented on 2020-06-22T21:08:40Z: As mentioned in #2628 , `experimental.host_callback` should provide a way to count NFE (and get other auxiliary information!) from `odeint`.

Comments:
- mattjj commented on 2020-02-11T16:44:28Z: Thanks for the feedback! I should've noted that this PR is a bit of a draft at the moment, and so I'm looking for early feedback.

> Why were the constants hoisted out of the computation in the first place? Is that reason still applicable?

There wasn't a good reason; it was just an artifact of the first way we wrote things.

One benefit we realized after the fact is that it automatically had the effect of avoiding staging into XLA a large constant into both a subcomputation (like in a while_loop) and the computation that contains it. I may try to solve that more directly on this PR.

> The motivation and the solution seem to not match.

Can you say more? They seem to match in my head, but maybe I didn't explain it well!
- gnecula commented on 2020-02-11T19:46:42Z: > > The motivation and the solution seem to not match.
> 
> Can you say more? They seem to match in my head, but maybe I didn't explain it well!

What I meant was that the problem to solve is to better control how pmap broadcasts inputs and outputs. This suggests that the solution should be some control mechanism for pmap broadcasting. Incidentally, it seems that we now have the mechanism through the `mapped_invars`. 

Instead this solution is changing how we trace Python into Jaxpr and changes even how Jaxpr looks. This could have broader consequences, and also introduces a hidden dependency of pmap on how we trace constants. This reminds me very much of the freevars and how pmap was implicitly taking advantage of them, but it was not possible to see this unless you try to remove freevars. 
- mattjj commented on 2020-02-11T20:03:11Z: I agree that if we had both mapped_invars _and_ mapped_outvars that would give us another way of solving this. That’s what I pointed out when I wrote “An alternative solution would be...” Indeed that’s the first solution I thought of!

But that solution is heavyweight for this particular issue. Unless we have a good reason to plumb constants as outputs of a pmap, why not revise that instead? And indeed this is a revision to jaxprs, like we’ve been doing a lot of recently :) (I might try removing constants entirely now...)

This isn’t introducing a dependency of pmap on how we handle constants; you’ll notice I didn’t change the pmap code, but instead I just changed which things are hoisted as constants versus literals and everything kept working. We could flip a coin to decide whether to treat each value as a hoisted constant or a literal and it would still work. But it’s preferable to treat things as literals because it’s more efficient, hence the PR. 

Can you think of any reasons to prefer the constant-hoisting behavior?

- mattjj commented on 2020-02-11T20:06:10Z: (By the way, handling a pmap with mapped_outvars is tricky because, for example, when doing jvp or partial eval we don’t know until we run the function how many outputs there will be. It’s doable but much heavier than anything in this PR!)
- gnecula commented on 2020-02-11T21:43:15Z: To be clear, if you say there were no important reasons to hoist constants, I like the change. If we can remove hoisted consts, I think that Jaxpr will be even simpler :-) 

I see that you did not change the code for pmap, yet you fixed how it behaves. This suggests that the dependency is implicit. I would have thought that with or without hoisting the semantics should be the same. 
- gnecula commented on 2020-02-12T13:46:52Z: If you do agree to try to remove the constvars, then I'd be happy to do that. I assume that some work would be needed for the linearity-bitmaps for scan and while, and also maybe something for compilation (perhaps hoisting them out only for compilation)?
- jakevdp commented on 2023-11-09T00:47:35Z: Closing, as non-scalar literals are now supported!

Comments:
- joaogui1 commented on 2020-02-08T04:53:55Z: The Hessian test was using the fact that the grad of max(x, x) = 0.5, since I'm proposing setting that grad to 1.0 I had to change the test
- fehiepsi commented on 2020-02-22T20:29:49Z: `grad max(x,y) = 0.5` makes sense to me. At least, we won't face grad issue of `x = max(x, 0) + min(x, 0)`. :D I found the definition helpful for [cross_entropy_with_logits](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/nn/sigmoid_cross_entropy_with_logits), where the function is `max(x, 0) - x * z + log(1 + exp(-abs(x)))`, which involves both `max` and `abs`. With `grad max(x,y) = 0.5`, the gradient of `cross_entropy` at (0, 0) will be correct.
- joaogui1 commented on 2020-02-22T21:48:48Z: If we use let the grad of min(0, 0) = 0.0 the first part is a non-issue I believe, but indeed getting the correct grad for cross-entropy is extremely important. 
Bummer, I wonder if there's a definition of the grad that works for all the cases.
In any case, the original problem this PR was meant to fix is going to be fixed by a custom grad and as you pointed out I would end up breaking other stuff, so I'm closing this, thanks for the input!
- yingted commented on 2020-03-09T23:34:00Z: I think there's a definition of grad that's consistent with the C/NumPy functions, if we ignore NaN:
max(x,y) = the larger one, or x if they're equal
abs(x) = x if x>0 or x is +0, otherwise -x
Then, max(-0,0) = -0, max(0,-1) = 0, and abs(-0) = 0.

The downside is that it probably breaks even more things.
You can still do many things, but not as easily:
- (min(x,y), max(x,y)) becomes (min(x,y), max(y,x))  (stable sort)
- max(x,0) + min(x,0) becomes max(x,0) + min(0,x)  (same as above, y=0)
- (min(x,y), abs(x-y)) becomes (min(x,y), max(y,x)-min(x,y))

Maybe the goal could be something like: either find a sound-but-not-complete approach to map keyword arguments to positional parameters, or else identify once and for all the reason we can't. WDYT?

Also, what do you think about just using `inspect.signature(f).bind(*args, **kwargs).args`? That seems to handle some simple cases:

```python
In [2]: inspect.signature(lambda x, y: x + y).bind(y=2, x=3).args
Out[2]: (3, 2)

In [3]: inspect.signature(lambda x, y: x + y).bind(2, y=3).args
Out[3]: (2, 3)
```

We could throw in some `apply_defaults` if we want:

```python
In [5]: ba = inspect.signature(lambda x, y=3: x + y).bind(2)

In [6]: ba.apply_defaults()

In [7]: ba.args
Out[7]: (2, 3)
```

IIUC that would already let us handle more cases than we do now, since it effectively turns more args into positional ones.

I'd like to red-team this to make sure we can never be misled by reasonable metadata values though, and produce silently wrong results... Is there any way to make a wrapper that would, instead of just obscuring the signature (causing us to error when keyword arguments are passed), actually make us bind incorrect values? Or is that only possible with malicious setting of `__wrapped__` or something like that?
- mattjj commented on 2020-01-28T06:12:15Z: Ah, I misread the code, maybe using `sig.bind` is exactly your strategy; I didn't understand the need for the rest of the code (ie why define `_fun`), but maybe it's to handle keyword-only args (which are new to me, coming from py2).

(I should have read your PR comment first, but instead I just looked at the code ;) )
- mattjj commented on 2020-01-28T06:22:18Z: By the way, linear_util.py already supports keyword arguments everywhere AFAIK.

+1 to profiling this. Perhaps we only need to call into this when keyword arguments are actually used.

Also +1 to raising errors: we don't need to have a complete solution, and just handling more cases than we currently do would be an improvement!

Here's one way we might write this in a linear_util.py style:

```python
from inspect import signature
from functools import partial

from jax import jit
import jax.linear_util as lu

def make_args_positional(f):
  return _make_args_positional(lu.wrap_init(f), signature(f)).call_wrapped

@lu.transformation
def _make_args_positional(sig, *args, **kwargs):
  ba = sig.bind(*args, **kwargs)
  ba.apply_defaults()
  ans = yield ba.args, ba.kwargs
  yield ans

@make_args_positional
@partial(jit, static_argnums=(1,))
def f(x, y):
  return x + y

f(2, y=3)  # fails if @make_args_positional is removed

@make_args_positional
@partial(jit, static_argnums=(1,))
def g(x, y, **kwargs):
  return x + y + kwargs['z']

g(2, y=3, z=2)  # works b/c we make enough args positional

@make_args_positional
@partial(jit, static_argnums=(1,))
def h(x, **kwargs):
  return x + kwargs['y'] + kwargs['z']

h(2, y=3, z=2)  # raises same error as usual
```

(Making it an extra transformation this way might even be useful as an API, to make it opt-in behavior, though I'm not sure that's a good idea.)
- ziyadedher commented on 2020-01-28T13:50:04Z: @mattjj Thanks for taking a look at this! Yes, the reason I had to make a new function was to get around the keyword-only argument issue; however, doing that breaks the caching system since we are now constructing a new function object at every `jit` call and using that as our `jitted` function. To get around this, I used a very hacky wrapper class that emulates (to the greatest extent possible in vanilla Python) the inputted function while still converting the arguments correctly:

```python
  class Fun:
    def __init__(self, fun):
      self.fun = fun

    def __call__(self, *args):
      fun_params = list(fun_sig.parameters.values())
      new_args = []
      new_kwargs = {}
      for arg, param in zip(args, fun_params):
        if param.kind is inspect.Parameter.KEYWORD_ONLY:
          new_kwargs[param.name] = arg
        else:
          new_args.append(arg)
      return self.fun(*new_args, **new_kwargs)

    def __hash__(self):
      return hash(self.fun)

    def __eq__(self, other):
      return self.fun == other

    def __getattr__(self, name):
      if name == "fun":
        return super().__getattribute__("fun")
      else:
        return self.fun.__getattribute__(name)

    def __getattribute__(self, name):
      if name == "__init__":
        return functools.partial(Fun.__init__, self)
      elif name == "__call__":
        return functools.partial(Fun.__call__, self)
      elif name == "__hash__":
        return functools.partial(Fun.__hash__, self)
      elif name == "__eq__":
        return functools.partial(Fun.__eq__, self)
      else:
        return Fun.__getattr__(self, name)
  _fun = Fun(fun)
```
However, this then raised a new issue where since we are using a `WeakKeyRef` dictionary and the instance of this class is created within the `jit` function, all strong references are lost and the function is dropped from cache anyway.

---

I will be playing around with the code example you gave today and see where it takes me, it's probably a lot less fragile than the current approach.

- mattjj commented on 2020-04-22T21:34:44Z: Thanks for starting this! I'm just paging it in again now, and asked some other folks whether asv makes sense for microbenchmarks for us. @shoyer and @jakevdp seem to think so!

We probably want to use [`block_until_ready`](https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/async_dispatch.html) right?
- mattjj commented on 2020-04-22T21:56:57Z: Maybe we can separate out two questions:
1. What benchmark harness should we use? asv seems to make sense now, but also perhaps this is easy to change later as needed, so it's a Type 2 decision (in the Jeff Bezos sense).
2. What should we start with in our microbenchmark suite? We should probably think about what each thing is measuring.

The former I'm not too concerned about. On the latter, I wonder if we can try to come up with a rationale for each test, and only commit ones that have some rationale behind them. For example, some things to measure and track are:

1. jit versus op-by-op dispatch times (say directly calling some `lax` primitives, like `lax.add`), since the latter has a special-case path only for performance reasons
2. cache hit versus cache miss cases for the above
3. numpy.ndarray aguments versus jax DeviceArray arguments to jitted functions
4. some key numpy functions of interest to which we might want to apply jit or otherwise look into speeding up
5. overheads from dtype and shape promotion logic

(I'm setting aside pmap and ShardedDeviceArray ideas because those may be harder to meaningfully test in OSS.)

Those might not be the right rationales, but perhaps we can iterate here. What signals do we want to track out of this? Avoiding regressions? Monitoring progress for specific overheads we've identified and want to improve on? (Keep in mind I'm focused on microbenchmarks only in this comment.)
- mattjj commented on 2020-04-22T21:59:35Z: This might give us an alternative to asv: https://github.com/google/benchmark/pull/957. I need to learn more from our Google / DM colleagues about it. Will report back when I do!

https://github.com/google/jax/blob/0c0137d787830d8ebd584c4610f7932f3787cab6/tests/lax_control_flow_test.py#L1307-L1318

Conjugate gradients inverts positive symmetric matrices, so this would look something like:
```python
    def _cg_solve(matvec, b):
      # your existing cg function, written with lax.while_loop

    def cg(matvec, b):
      # exposed as scipy.sparse.cg
      return lax.custom_linear_solve(matvec, b, _cg_solve, symmetric=True)
```

My other suggestion would be to write to write this in terms of a function that calculates matrix-vector products. For dense matrices, other methods like Cholesky factorization are usually more efficient. CG really shines for inverting very large but sparse systems of equations, e.g., where the dense matrix might have 1e6 x1e6 elements, which is too big to fit into memory.

- gehring commented on 2019-11-11T22:05:51Z: >  For instance, should collect(jvp(f)) only collect the primal values of named intermediates, or both the primals and tangents (and if the latter, how should they be returned)?

I believe I would expect output to either only contain the intermediate values of tangents/co-tangents (for example, if some custom jvp implementation pushed some intermediates), or have it return both the primal's and tangent's. For the former, you could still get the primals if you wanted to if a `value_and_jvp` function was available.

With only reading the text above, here are the semantics I might expect. By default, primitives should simply propagate intermediates, i.e., identity on intermediates (which I believe is the case here), but I agree that what higher order operators should do is less clear. I think if you say that differentiation wipes all intermediates, you might get jvps returning only tangent intermediates while if you say that differentiation propagates intermediates, you would likely get jvp returning both primal and tangent. It's not quite clear what kind of low-level rule might lead to only getting intermediates of the primals.

There are probably lots of edge cases/caveat that I've missed but I thought sharing my first impressions will probably provide a better approximation of what a new user might think.

> Similarly, I think the right thing to do in inject/collect of vmap is to accept/return batched intermediate values with the batch dimension in the vmap's out_dim, but that might be a little surprising for inject. Pull Request 1577 titled 'All to all fix' was created by levskaya (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- mattjj commented on 2019-10-28T16:52:29Z: This is actually a change from our original design. (It's a separate question as to whether the existing implementation was _wrong_ in that they didn't implement our original design.)

The original design was that the split axis size must be _equal_ to the mapped axis size, so that this operation was in effect a transpose with the mapped axis. That is, we didn't want to talk about chunks. We can always recover the "chunked" operation by using a reshape.

More generally, the semantics of our `pmap` collectives can't exactly match XLA's because with `pmap` the parallel axis is fully mapped and identified with a name, while with XLA there is no concept of mapped axis. This difference is especially salient in this `all_to_all` primitive, which effectively transposes mapped and logical (positional) axes with one another.

Before diving into any implementation details, let's figure out what design we want, and work out some examples. Do you have some examples of computations you want to express?

- hawkinsp commented on 2019-09-30T13:09:10Z: @gehring I haven't forgotten about reviewing this, but I've been out of office a lot. I'll take a look when I can.

@MostafaDehghani Usually when you are looking for that kind of transpose operation, you can use the reverse-mode gradient, or VJP.

`jax.vjp` should let you do what you need here: use `jax.vjp` on `extract_image_patches` with a cotangent containing the image patches to sum. If there are overlapping image patches, the VJP will sum the contributions all of them. To take the mean, which I assume is what you want, you can use `jax.vjp` with a cotangent of all 1s to count the number of contributions to each pixel, then divide the sum by the count. Hope that helps!
- MostafaDehghani commented on 2019-10-07T08:20:03Z: Hi, 

Just for the record, wanted to post this small example of how to reconstruct the original image given the output of extract_image_patches using  jax.vjp. 

```
im_height = im_width = 6
patch_height = patch_width = 2
im = np.arange(im_height * im_width).reshape(-1, im_height, im_width,1).astype(np.float32)


def i2p(im):
  return extract_image_patches(
          lhs=im.astype(np.float64),
          rhs_shape=(1,patch_height, patch_width,1),
          window_strides=(1,patch_height, patch_width,1), 
          padding='VALID',
          rhs_dilation=(1,1,1,1),
          data_format='NHWC')

def p2i(im_patched):
    _, fn_vjp = jax.vjp(i2p, np.ones(im.shape))
    overlap_count = fn_vjp(np.ones_like(im_patched))[0]
    return fn_vjp(im_patched)[0] / overlap_cou

im_patched = i2p(im).squeeze()
recunstructed_im = p2i(im_patched)
assert np.array_equal(recunstructed_im, im)
```
Thanks  again @hawkinsp for the help! :)

Comments:
- mattjj commented on 2019-07-21T03:36:04Z: Awesome! Super clean, too.

That first issue definitely sounds like a `custom_transforms` issue, though I think a known/intended one: defining a VJP, rather than a JVP and/or a transpose directly, is just done by creating a dummy JVP object. So by defining the VJP here you're clobbering the JVP rule you wrote.

I think the best approach, if we can make the math work out how we want, would be to define a JVP and a transpose rule here. After all, a VJP is just a JVP bundled together with partial evaluation and transposition; if we can decompose them we'll be in business, and possibly have less code to boot. (Or if we discover there are cases that we can't effectively decompose the VJP into a JVP and a transpose, and this is one of them, we'll have to figure out a different technique!)

(FYI I'm traveling for a few more days and hence low bandwidth, but I'd love to help with this!)
- shoyer commented on 2019-07-30T22:27:50Z: My benchmarks here were mistaken because I was not accounting for async dispatch. There are use cases for using adjoint-like rules to directly define gradients, but this particular case does not seems to be one of them.

I'm not sure this is the right fix, though. I don't think we want to support `None` in the `input_shape` argument to a stax `init_fun`. It should be a tuple of integers. We can use -1 when we don't want to commit to a batch shape, though even that's a bit sloppy (because we really want to create a shape variable, but since the abstract evaluation shape rules were written to act on tuples of integers, using -1 is a hacky shortcut).

- craffel commented on 2019-01-14T20:43:40Z: In that case, if supporting Google is most important then I think it would make sense to re-write the code to not use `take_along_axis` at all, since it's probably cleaner to support the lowest common denominator than it is to try to support either conditionally. But I defer to whatever your support philosophy is.
- mattjj commented on 2019-01-14T20:45:55Z: Ah but we don't use it except to test against it (and to read its docstring for wrapping purposes). We *provide* it, regardless of the numpy version.
- craffel commented on 2019-01-14T20:48:23Z: So are you proposing to conditionally not test against it if it's not available? Because otherwise it still seems like you will need to reimplement it, but maybe I am missing something.
- mattjj commented on 2019-01-14T20:53:50Z: Exactly! I'll make a PR.

- jakevdp commented on 2023-03-08T02:26:25Z: @b0nce FYI
- b0nce commented on 2023-03-08T10:38:23Z: Hey, @jakevdp, should I re-open PR with fixes, or what should we do next?
I guess it again an issue with type casting on some specific machine, and the only place we can have this issue is `arctan` [here](https://github.com/b0nce/jax/blob/feb9ab33af9a2506429b94bef5dd6ddefbd06d01/jax/_src/scipy/stats/cauchy.py#L46), since it's an only [subtraction](https://github.com/b0nce/jax/blob/feb9ab33af9a2506429b94bef5dd6ddefbd06d01/jax/_src/scipy/stats/cauchy.py#L57) with a function which has a bind to unknown code. All other places in PR already have casted types, or guarantees for the same output type (like [ntdr](https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_autosummary/jax.scipy.special.ndtr.html) [here](https://github.com/b0nce/jax/blob/feb9ab33af9a2506429b94bef5dd6ddefbd06d01/jax/_src/scipy/stats/norm.py#L46)).

- francois-rozet commented on 2024-07-26T20:07:47Z: Hello @yashk2810, I will take a look at this PR. Could you try to summarize the remaining issues?

By the way, what do you expect to happen when a function is "jitted" under `config.enable_x64(True)` and used outside?

```python
with config.enable_x64(True):
    @jax.jit
    def f(x):
        return jax.numpy.fft(x)

    x = jax.numpy.linspace(0, 1, 256)
    y = f(x)

y_bis = f(x)  # dtype?
```

Similarly, what about gradients?

```python
with config.enable_x64(True):
    def f(x):
        return jax.numpy.fft(x)

    x = jax.numpy.linspace(0, 1, 256)
    y, vjp = jax.vjp(f)(x)

grad = vjp(jnp.ones_like(y))  # dtype?
```

or

```python
def f(x):
    with config.enable_x64(True):
        return jax.numpy.fft(x)

x = jax.numpy.linspace(0, 1, 256)
y, vjp = jax.vjp(f)(x)  # dtype?
grad = vjp(jnp.ones_like(y))  # dtype?
```

Body: No description available

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2024-02-29T00:09:06Z: Thanks! This looks like it may be useful, but I find that constructing the new error text fails in some cases; for example:
```python
>>> import jax.numpy as jnp
>>> x = jnp.arange(5)
>>> x[{}]
...
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'dtype'
```
Can you update to construct the error string more defensively?
- curlup commented on 2024-03-14T22:52:38Z: should be better now, not sure if you meant it exactly that way though @jakevdp 
- jakevdp commented on 2024-03-14T23:16:43Z: I still think we need to be more defensive. You solved the particular case I mentioned, but I think it's certainly possible that if `abstract_i` won't have a `dtype` attribute even if `i` is `None`. That check is a bit of an "action at a distance" – it makes assumptions about the relationship between the two variables that is difficult for the reader of the code to ascertain without searching elsewhere in the file. That's kind of an antipattern, because it makes the code brittle and harder to maintain.

What about something like this instead?
```python
       raise IndexError("Indexing mode not yet supported. Got unsupported indexer "
                        f"at position {idx_pos}: {i}")
```
- curlup commented on 2024-03-15T16:53:51Z: Sure, totally makes sense, should've thought of that myself 
(PS I wonder if there could be like a guiding doc for stuff like that. I know it's pretty minimal, but would be nice to have self-service PR self-review enabled by something like that)
- curlup commented on 2024-04-05T18:34:26Z: > Looks good, thanks! The last thing we'll need here is to squash all the changes into a single commit (see https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/contributing.html#single-change-commits-and-pull-requests). Pull Request 17902 titled '[typing] annotate jax.numpy scalar types with JAXScalarType' was created by jakevdp (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2023-10-03T19:18:57Z: @hawkinsp - requesting some early feedback on this approach. There will likely be a lot of work required to land a change like this, similar to what we did with the rest of `jax/numpy/__init__.pyi`
- jakevdp commented on 2023-10-03T19:27:48Z: Another option would be to avoid the `Protocol` and annotate them more directly as `_ScalarMeta`, I'm not sure which I'd prefer. `JAXScalarType` may be nicer because it's more human readable.
- hawkinsp commented on 2023-10-04T18:56:15Z: I think I like the protocol over exposing the implementation details

I might not call it `JAXScalarType` because the `JAX` is somewhat redundant.

Overall I'm in favor of  doing something like this.
- jakevdp commented on 2023-10-04T23:09:36Z: > I might not call it `JAXScalarType` because the `JAX` is somewhat redundant.

Renamed to `ScalarType`
- jakevdp commented on 2023-10-12T20:55:42Z: Some updates here: there is a *ton* of downstream code that uses annotations like `-> jnp.float32` ([codesearch](https://github.com/search?q=%22-%3E+jnp.float%22+lang%3Apython&type=code)), which will never be valid: it's impossible to create instances of the type `float32` because JAX doesn't have scalar types.

Still, the intent of those annotations is clear: users want an annotation that communicates both to the reader of the code and to the static type checker that the input is an array (or perhaps array-like) with a float32 dtype.

I'm wondering now whether we'll need to provide some dtype-specific array annotations before we can land something like this change.
- hawkinsp commented on 2023-10-13T14:15:00Z: I agree. We can certainly land this change as is (it makes the world better), but we certainly should see if we can better capture the dtype before forcing everyone to migrate to `jax.Array` as a type annotation.
- jakevdp commented on 2023-11-06T20:43:16Z: I'm going to close this for now – there are far too many uses of `jnp.float32` and others as type annotations (currently valid as they are aliases of `Any`) and I'm not sure how to proceed without a decent typed array replacement.

Should be the "best".
It seems that if newest `jax` was installed but `jaxlib` is stale(or without cuda), `pip install "jax[cuda11_cudnn84]" -f https://storage.googleapis.com/jax-releases/jax_cuda_releases.html` won't install desired `jaxlib` since `jax` requirement already satisfied.
- jakevdp commented on 2022-07-14T16:35:52Z: I've seen variations of this before – `pip`'s handling of optional dependences (the things in brackets) does not always interact well with `--upgrade`. To ensure you're getting the most recent versions of what you specify, I'd suggest this instead:
```
pip uninstall jax jaxlib
pip install jax[...
```

- jakevdp commented on 2022-02-11T17:59:02Z: @NeilGirdhar My understanding is that the type annotation is incorrect because the returned object adds some methods; e.g. type checkers will incorrectly fail on the following:
```python
from jax import jit
@jit
def f(x):
  return x
lowered = f.lower(1.0)  # <--- original function has no `lower` method, so type checking fails
```
The full solution would proably be to define some custom protocol, but in the meantime `Any` is not incorrect.

Right, that would be a better solution.
- NeilGirdhar commented on 2022-02-14T09:54:29Z: @jakevdp By the way, I looked into it, but MyPy has bugs relating to that protocol: https://github.com/python/mypy/issues/12169.  So I guess, I won't be able to get that protocol using `ParamSpec` until MyPy has fixes.  Could we use a protocol that doesn't use `ParamSpec`?

Something like this:

```python
T = TypeVar("T", covariant=True)

# TODO: Use ParamSpec to annotate function parameters.
class JittedFunction(Protocol, Generic[T]):
  def __call__(self, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any) -> T:
    ...

  def lower(self, *args: Any, **kwargs: Any) -> Lowered:
    ...
```

And then where you have `Callable`, you could have `Callable[..., T]` and you could return `JittedFunction[T]`.  What do you think?

Pull Request 6642 titled 're-export `dtype_real` from jax.dtypes' was created by PhilipVinc (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2021-05-04T16:51:54Z: Hi - thanks for flagging this.

The change you reference deliberately cleaned up JAX's public API. We chatted a bit about this offline, and I think we'd prefer for this utility to not be part of JAX's public API, as it really has more to do with numpy dtypes than anything special to JAX. If you want a quick way to get this result, you can do something like this:
```python
def dtype_real(dtype):
  return np.finfo(dtype).dtype if np.issubdtype(dtype, np.complexfloating) else dtype
```
- PhilipVinc commented on 2021-05-05T18:13:14Z: I see.
Indeed it might be something that should be in numpy.  
But it isn't.
Most people probably don't use complex numbers, but since jax's support of complex numbers in AD is somewhat... contrived, this is a fundamental function to have. 

Looking at jax.dtpes I see the following symbols:
```python
>>> jax.dtypes.
jax.dtypes.bfloat16(            jax.dtypes.finfo(               jax.dtypes.iinfo(               jax.dtypes.result_type(
jax.dtypes.canonicalize_dtype(  jax.dtypes.float0               jax.dtypes.issubdtype(          jax.dtypes.scalar_type_of(
```

`result_type` In particular! if I need to compute the result type of an operation that is R->R or C->R, I have the need for `dtype_real`, otherwise how can I compute the result?

This, for me, is telling that it is essential when computing dtypes.
- jakevdp commented on 2021-05-05T18:19:53Z: I'm not certain I understand the comparison you're making to `result_type`, which is basically JAX's version of `np.result_type` specialized to JAX's promotion logic.

The `dtype_real` utility is only used in one place in JAX; unless there are good arguments for keeping it, I'd probably be in favor of removing it altogether.
- PhilipVinc commented on 2021-05-07T10:53:46Z: My argument is that `np.result_type` allows you to compute the type promotion logic of some operation involving two types. 
So if I write a custom jax primitive doing something like a sum `+(a,b) = a+b`, I can implement the abstract evaluation logic using `np.result_type(a, b)`.
But If I write a custom jax primitive doing something like a norm `custom(a) = a.conj()*a` the abstract evaluation logic needs `dtype_real`. You can write your own, `dtype_real` with a series of `if,else`, but that is ugly.

use cases I have for it are (what we are using it in NetKet): 
  - computing the resulting `dtype` of statistical objects (variance, autocorrelation time...) which are all real-valued even if the input data is complex-valued. 
  - In some layers with precise mathematical properties, we want some parameters to be real no matter what, while the rest can be complex too. We ask the user to specify the dtype of the layer, which can be any floating-point type, but then need to extract the `real_dtype`.

In essence, yes, `dtype_real` is fairly niche in that not a lot of people care about complex numbers.

For people who care about complex numbers, this is an important tool and avoids littering the code with 
`dtype_real= lambda typ:jnp.ones((), typ)).real` or smarter implementations. 

Again, I do think that this should be a numpy thing really, but as it's not, I think it's a fairly useful thing to be included in jax.
- jakevdp commented on 2021-05-07T12:30:28Z: Thanks for outlining your thinking. It still seems to me that a utility that's not specific to JAX, is used only once in all the JAX codebase, and that can be reproduced in a single line is not a great candidate to be part of the public API.
Pull Request 6545 titled 'Support `dtype` kwarg in `jnp.matmul`' was created by lgeiger (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2021-04-22T21:51:48Z: There seems to be one difference here that I can see: in Numpy, this works:
```python
x = np.ones((4, 4)).astype('float64')
np.matmul(x, x, dtype='float32')
```
The equivalent operation in JAX fails with the error
```
TypeError: `preferred_element_type` must not be narrower than the original type.
```
There's a similar issue when changing the kind of type via `dtype`:
```python
x = np.ones((4, 4)).astype('int64') 
np.matmul(x, x, dtype='float64')  # <-- no error

x = jnp.ones((4, 4)).astype('int64') 
jnp.matmul(x, x, dtype='float64') 
# TypeError: `preferred_element_type` and the original type must both be integral, both be floating point, or both complex.
```
I think this keyword needs a bit more handling to match numpy's semantics.
- lgeiger commented on 2021-04-23T20:01:23Z: > I think this keyword needs a bit more handling to match numpy's semantics.

@jakevdp Good point, sorry for missing that.

I updated the PR to handle numpy semantics.
This now adds quite a bit of additional code to handle type casting.
So I think in a broader context this PR only makes sense if you plan to add support for the `dtype` keyword argument to other `ufuncs` as well in the future (see e.g #1364). I'll let you decide if support for this argument is worth the added maintenance burden or whether this is something that will be deliberately not supported by JAX in which case I am happy to close this PR.
- jakevdp commented on 2021-05-03T19:01:11Z: Sorry, I looked a bit closer at this and I think it needs a bit more thought. In particular, the handling of the `casting` argument seems different than numpy: here it is only referenced if `dtype is None`. I think (though I may be wrong?) that in numpy the `casting` argument applies to casting of the inputs as well.

Back to your previous comment, we may want to step back and decide whether it is a goal to handle optional ufunc keywords consistently across jax; I'm not certain what the answer is.
- lgeiger commented on 2021-05-03T20:07:38Z: >  I think (though I may be wrong?) that in numpy the casting argument applies to casting of the inputs as well.

Good catch. Yes, I think you are right. I would need to look into it a bit more closely, but I think numpy uses something like the following logic:
```python
result_dtype = dtype or np.result_type(a, b)
if not (np.can_cast(a.dtype, result_dtype) and np.can_cast(b.dtype, result_dtype))
    raise
```

> Back to your previous comment, we may want to step back and decide whether it is a goal to handle optional ufunc keywords consistently across jax; I'm not certain what the answer is.

I agree, this is something that should be handled for all ufuncs consistently. I think a first step would be to decide whether it is within the scope of JAX to support the `casting` argument in all ufuncs. Once JAX follows the same ufunc casting rules as numpy, supporting user definable result dtypes should be pretty easy. But then again the question whether the added maintenance burden for supporting all ufunc arguments is a worthwhile investment is still not obvious.

Registering the module for exclusion, as in your proposed change, won't filter all frames from `lax` on its own. Frames would still be included if a `lax` function is called directly (with no transformation like `jit`, `vmap`, etc.). To handle the direct call case, we need to mark every function in `lax` as an `api_boundary`.

Pull Request 4117 titled 'Support overriding implementations of JAX functions within a scope' was created by shoyer (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- juliuskunze commented on 2020-08-21T11:16:05Z: @shoyer This feature could potentially allow a large speedup of `jnp` functions running on the NumPy backend: `numpy_eval()(jnp.<some_fun>)` could be mapped directly to `np.<some_fun>`, instead of tracing `jnp.<some_fun>` and calling the NumPy implementations of the encountered lax primitives. It might make https://github.com/google/jax/issues/3893 fast out-of-the-box, removing the need to keep optimized NumPy implementations of shape rules.
- shoyer commented on 2020-08-21T21:25:16Z: @JuliusKunze I would be a little reluctant to support directly overriding `jax.numpy` functions. JAX works so well in part because transformations are written at the LAX primitive level, which is a much more uniform and rationalized interface than `jax.numpy`. That's the main reason why I suggested this interface as a temporary measure -- it would be much better (if possible) to figure out a uniform interface for threading variables holding mutable state through transformations.
- NeilGirdhar commented on 2021-02-05T11:18:10Z: Whoa, this is awesome!!  This would resolve my problem in Haiku (linked above) and it seems very versatile too.  What's the future of this pull request?
- jekbradbury commented on 2021-02-07T07:12:46Z: I think I support this. We haven't made any progress on a unified state mechanism since the last time this was proposed, and it's better than external libraries directly monkeypatching JAX. Note that most libraries that provide state-aware versions of functions like `jit`, `scan`, etc. add additional knobs/functionality to those functions (and not necessarily in a mutually compatible way), so this feature doesn't solve all aspects of the problem.
- shoyer commented on 2021-02-07T19:31:25Z: Since drafting this, we actually have use-case for this in our own application code where `haiku.scan` wasn't quite right and we wanted our own version.

My one thought is that we should probably make it clearer that it's experimental. If we don't think it's worth making a new experimental module, perhaps we should just include "experimental" in the name, e.g., `jax.experimental_override_context`? Or perhaps it can just live in the top-level `jax.experimental` namespace along with the `enable_x64`/`disable_x64` context managers.
- shoyer commented on 2021-02-07T22:43:03Z: This is ready for review now.
- NeilGirdhar commented on 2021-02-08T01:53:58Z: Wow, I appreciate how fast the Jax team responds to issues!

I'm just curious, would it be worth adding the `eval_shape` override to the list?  Haiku seems to provide an override.
- froystig commented on 2021-02-08T03:50:35Z: Placing `override_context` in `experimental` sounds good to me.
- shoyer commented on 2021-02-08T05:50:00Z: > I'm just curious, would it be worth adding the `eval_shape` override to the list? Haiku seems to provide an override.

Yes, absolutely!

I think I got them all, but let me know if you notice any others that are missing. (It's also easy to extend this in the future, of course.)
- shoyer commented on 2021-02-10T00:38:03Z: Tests are passing -- is anyone from the JAX team up for a review?
- shoyer commented on 2021-02-26T17:39:25Z: After discussion with the whole JAX team, we decided _not_ to go further with this PR at this time. It solves some real problems (writing library code that uses higher order functions that wants to be compatible with stateful transformations), but:

1. Clearly isn't the ultimate solution (which would be some universal system for managing state _inside_ JAX)
2. It is still something that is going to require application specific choices. For example, if you `scan` over a neural net layer, should the weights be scanned over or not?

For now, the recommendation is to write your own, library specific implementations of higher order functions like `scan` and your own scope for overrides, if necessary.

- gnecula commented on 2020-05-11T10:19:45Z: Thank you for helping clean up the documentation. If instead we do want JAX-specific documentation, I think that it is best to put it next to the 
definition of `jax.numpy.sqrt` instead of a separate file. My thinking is that there is no point in inventing a new mechanism for associating documentation with definitions. 

@skye PTAL

- gnecula commented on 2020-05-11T11:55:54Z: Re: `where`, I just wanted to make sure that I understand the scope of the changes, since it was not mentioned in #2979 as a problem. JAX does not support it and it is fine that is missing from the documentation. 

I am assuming that needing a custom documentation is the exception, not the common case. In those cases, I think it is preferable to add a docstring where the function is defined, rather than 
putting it in a separate file, for the same reason that `numpy` has the documentation in docstrings rather than in a separate file. 

My preference would be to just have a short paragraph that explains how JAX's version is different than numpy (assuming the differences are small and easily explainable), and then include verbatim the numpy documentation. This way we do not have to maintain a 
separate documentation string than numpy. 

We can see what Skye thinks also. @skye 
 
- hawkinsp commented on 2020-05-11T13:39:53Z: Another comment is that we must respect copyright here. I haven't looked into the details, but at a minimum anything copied from NumPy (e.g., doc strings) must go in the `third_party/numpy` directory.
- skye commented on 2020-05-11T16:18:41Z: I like this proposal. Peter correctly points out we should put the docstrings in `jax/third_party/numpy`, which sounds like reason enough for putting the docstrings in a separate file, so I won't go into why I thought it was a good idea even without the copyright consideration.

We could just add a note to the top of the documentation. As I see it, the upshot is that we don't need this extra complexity. The downside is lower-quality documentation (e.g. "blah blah blah ... please disregard the confusing bit below ... confusing bit ...", and in this case the confusing bit is highlighted in an eye-catching box). There's probably some argument about updates to the original numpy documentation, but I think that could go either way depending on if the updates still align with what our version of the function does :) Am I missing anything?

I think it's worth having the higher-quality documentation, and it clears the way for future improvements of this kind. However, I'd also be ok adding the note for now and seeing if it comes up for other numpy functions.
- gnecula commented on 2020-05-11T17:16:27Z: I'd be interested to know how many cases we know of where we need to have custom documentation, and what are the cases when it is really awkward to rely on a comment at the top to list unimplemented or different behavior.

- gnecula commented on 2020-05-14T08:52:24Z: Let's try to make progress on this. I see that several of us have expressed reservations about making an almost-copy of the numpy documentation. I think that the maintainability cost is still an issue even if we put it in third_party/numpy. How about the following compromise:

* We have the option to add a custom docstring to lax.numpy primitives, along with the definition of the primitive.
* The _wrap function will do what it does already, except that it can insert this custom docstring before it includes the original numpy implementation
* We put in that custom docstring only what is specific about lax implementation. This may include notes about how it differs from the original numpy.

Would we still need to `import jax.numpy as np` to use op-by-op JAX execution on standard numpy ndarrays? In that case I guess users will need to use more explicit `jax.device_put` calls (if they don’t import `jax.numpy` as before. 

More importantly, this would change the behavior for anyone using `import numpy as onp`: where that could previously be used to convert to host-side ndarrays, now it might not, meaning users would need more explicit `jax.device_get` calls. 

Those might be good things, but I just want to make sure I’m understanding. It would be a nontrivial api change.
- shoyer commented on 2019-08-02T16:49:06Z: > Would we still need to `import jax.numpy as np` to use op-by-op JAX execution on standard numpy ndarrays? In that case I guess users will need to use more explicit `jax.device_put` calls (if they don’t import `jax.numpy` as before.

Yes, that would work. More practically, the easy way to ensure functions get executed with JAX is to use `jit`.

> More importantly, this would change the behavior for anyone using `import numpy as onp`: where that could previously be used to convert to host-side ndarrays, now it might not, meaning users would need more explicit `jax.device_get` calls.

That's right, this would be a breaking change for such code. Instead, users will need to write `onp.array()` explicitly to convert into NumPy arrays. It might be worth testing this change on our internal codebase to gauge its impact.

For the most part I expect this will should be fine -- JAX has mostly equivalent implementations of most commonly used NumPy functions.

One noteworthy case are functions like `np.unique()` that exist in NumPy but not JAX. In the current version of this PR, we raise an exception when you call these functions on JAX arrays. Instead, it would probably be more user-friendly to call `jax.device_get()` to load them into memory and issue a warning about functions not implemented by JAX.

- jekbradbury commented on 2019-03-15T00:26:52Z: It's pretty unfortunate that Python namedtuples don't have an abstract base class--in our context, it makes them indistinguishable from core JAX types implemented as tuple subclasses (like `PartialVal` and `JaxTuple`) which need to be treated as leaves for the purposes of `pytree`. Rather than special-casing named tuples, I went ahead and implemented the ability to register a type as a leaf, and registering those two tuple subclasses was enough to get tests to pass.

I'm not sure if I should also add leaf registration for `AbstractTuple`, `Destructuring`, and `JaxprTracerTuple` (or any others)--I haven't looked into whether any of those can appear in the trees passed to the tree_utils machinery (leaving them out hasn't broken any tests).
- jekbradbury commented on 2019-03-15T00:28:54Z: (Also, adding a test was a great idea, because it turns out the code in the original PR didn't actually do anything).
- levskaya commented on 2019-03-15T08:45:34Z: I like the idea!  I agree that the way namedtuples are implemented in python is pretty annoying.  As an aside, you _can_ make namedtuple equivalents that have a (non-tuple) base class, this is one that should work equivalently in py2/py3 for all the ways we use them in JAX:
```python
from collections import Sequence

class SaneNamedTuple(Sequence): 
    """Subclass and define named fields with __slots__."""
    __slots__ = ()
    def __init__(self, *args):
        for slot, arg in zip(self.__slots__, args):
            setattr(self, slot, arg)
    def __repr__(self):
        attr_repr = ', '.join(map(lambda x: "%s=%r"%(x[0], x[1]),
                         tuple(zip(self.__slots__, tuple(self)))))
        return '{name}({args})'.format(name=type(self).__name__, args=attr_repr)
    def __iter__(self): 
        for name in self.__slots__:
            yield getattr(self, name)
    def __getitem__(self, index):
        return getattr(self, self.__slots__[index])
    def __len__(self):
        return len(self.__slots__)

def sane_namedtuple(cls_name, attr_names):
  "Create a named tuple-like class with name cls_name and fields attr_names."
  assert isinstance(attr_names, (list, tuple))
  return type(cls_name,
              (SaneNamedTuple,), 
              {"__slots__": tuple(attr_names)})

Point = sane_namedtuple("Point", ("x", "y"))
pt = Point(1, 2)
print(pt)  # Point(x=1, y=2)
print(pt.x, pt.y)  # 1 2
print(isinstance(pt, Point))  # True
print(isinstance(pt, SaneNamedTuple))  # True
print(isinstance(pt, Sequence))  # True
print(isinstance(pt, tuple))  # False
x, y = pt
print(x, y)  # 1 2
```

Here that means that `SaneNamedTuple`s expose `*args` as their constructor signature rather than the set of fields in the named tuple.
- levskaya commented on 2019-03-16T03:09:42Z: @jekbradbury - I see what you want.  In python2 this is pretty much true. :(  In python3 we have the tools of inspect.Signature and inspect.Parameter which can set `__signature__` to do this though:
```python

    # ... in base class def:
    @classmethod
    def get_signature(cls):
        parameters = [
          Parameter(name=slot, kind=Parameter.POSITIONAL_OR_KEYWORD) for slot in cls.__slots__
        ]

```
yet another reason to drop py2 given it hasn't been improved in 10 years...
- levskaya commented on 2019-03-18T06:31:15Z: Sorry to keep distracting from the main point of this thread :)  to be concrete vis a vis above, this is the implementation of base-classable nametuple that I've seen before for py3.
```python
from collections import Sequence
from inspect import Signature, Parameter
class SaneNamedTuple(Sequence): 
    __slots__ = ()
    @classmethod
    def get_signature(cls):
        parameters = [Parameter(name=slot, kind=Parameter.POSITIONAL_OR_KEYWORD) 
                      for slot in cls.__slots__]
        return Signature(parameters=parameters)
    def __init_subclass__(cls, **kwargs):
        super().__init_subclass__(**kwargs)
        slots = cls.__slots__
        cls.__slots__ = (tuple(slots.split()) if isinstance(slots, str) else tuple(slots))
        cls.__signature__ = cls.get_signature()
        cls.__init__.__signature__ = cls.get_signature()
        cls.__doc__ = ('{cls.__name__}{cls.__signature__}\n\n{cls.__doc__}'.format(cls=cls))
    def __new__(cls, *args, **kwargs):
        if cls is SaneNamedTuple:
            raise TypeError("Can't instantiate abstract class SaneNamedTuple")
        return super().__new__(cls)
    @classmethod
    def _get_bound_args(cls, args, kwargs):
        return Signature.bind(cls.__signature__, *args, **kwargs).arguments.items()
    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
        bound_args = self._get_bound_args(args, kwargs)
        for slot, value in bound_args:
            setattr(self, slot, value)
    def __repr__(self):
        return type(self).__name__ + repr(tuple(self))
    def __iter__(self): 
        for name in self.__slots__:
            yield getattr(self, name)
    def __getitem__(self, index):
        return getattr(self, self.__slots__[index])
    def __len__(self):
        return len(self.__slots__)

def sane_namedtuple(cls_name, attr_names):
  "Create a named tuple-like class with name cls_name and fields attr_names."
  assert isinstance(attr_names, (list, tuple))
  return type(cls_name,
              (SaneNamedTuple,), 
              {"__slots__": tuple(attr_names)})
```
- NeilGirdhar commented on 2020-04-20T07:51:36Z: I've also been really interested in dealing with inheritance and pytrees.  I've been inheriting pytree-conversion like this:

https://github.com/NeilGirdhar/efax/blob/master/efax/tensors/tensor_like.py

You can see how it's used here:

https://github.com/NeilGirdhar/efax/blob/630b73dadab01271f794119a6d41f5b6fce1bb66/efax/tensors/jax_generator.py#L34

I have been using it with inheritance too.  When there is no extra information, the subclass inherits the pytree conversion.  When there are extra members, you can override the members, and have the overrides call super:

```python
    @classmethod
    def from_tensor(cls, values, aux_data):
        super_aux_data, distribution = aux_data
        r = super().from_tensor(values, super_aux_data)
        r.distribution = distribution
        return r

    def to_tensor(self):
        values, aux_data = super().to_tensor()
        return values, (aux_data, self.distribution)
```

One of the advantages of this inheritance approach is that it supports `isinstance` checks, and you can use `TensorLike` in type annotations.  For example, I have the following type annotations:

```python
Shape = Tuple[int, ...]
ShapeLike = Union[int, Sequence[int]]
SliceLike = Tuple[Union[int, None, slice], ...]
Tensor = Union[np.ndarray, jnp.ndarray]
PyTree = Union[Tensor, 'TensorLike', Container['PyTree']]
```

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2024-10-09T12:21:18Z: Does the function return reasonable results for complex input? If so, I don't think we should do this deprecation, as it would potentially break existing users with very little benefit.
- hawkinsp commented on 2024-10-09T14:13:56Z: @pearu would probably have the best opinion on "does this function return reasonable results for complex inputs?".
- jakevdp commented on 2024-10-09T14:29:37Z: It dispatches to `lax.atan2`, so I suspect the answer is yes for the sake of this discussion. (it's not returning garbage, it's actually attempting a valid computation).

My thinking here: in general JAX functionality is a superset of numpy functionality. So just because NumPy returns a TypeError doesn't mean JAX must as well. Does that make sense?
- rajasekharporeddy commented on 2024-10-10T05:08:28Z: Thanks for the clarification @jakevdp. Can I modify this PR to add the docstring for `arctan2`?
- pearu commented on 2024-10-11T10:20:42Z: atan2 is implemented in stablehlo, see https://github.com/openxla/stablehlo/blob/main/docs/spec.md#atan2 . Usually, arctan2 for complex inputs is not supported (for example, by numpy, torch, Python array API standard v2023.12, C++ numerics library, etc) as `atan2(y, x)` is associated with the direction angle of the point `(x, y)` in the  Cartesian coordinates. However, numerically, supporting `atan2` for complex inputs does make sense for cases where `x` is complex zero or close to complex zero, and ideally, `atan2(y, x)` should be more accurate than `atan(y / x)`.

That said, the current implementation of atan2 on complex inputs in stablehlo is problematic accuracy-wise. For example:
```python
>> x, y = 1+0.00001j, 1-0.00001j
>>> jnp.arctan2(y, x)   # the imaginary part is inaccurate
Array(0.7853981-1.001353e-05j, dtype=complex64, weak_type=True)
>>> jnp.arctan(y / x)   # expected
Array(0.7853982-1.e-05j, dtype=complex64, weak_type=True)
```
and atm I would recommend using `atan(y / x)` instead of `atan2(y, x)` when `x != 0+0j` (I'll add this issue to my todo list).

On the other hand, to allow the switch `numpy <-> jax.numpy` in both directions, the current PR makes sense, although, I second @jakevdp point that jax.numpy will likely never be equivalent to `numpy`.
- jakevdp commented on 2024-10-16T16:13:26Z: I think we should close this PR, because we shouldn't deprecate or raise an error for complex inputs to this function.
- rajasekharporeddy commented on 2024-10-17T02:15:36Z: Thanks! Closing the PR.

Body: No description available

Comments:
- mattjj commented on 2024-06-24T23:06:00Z: Thanks for checking over the docs! But actually it was correct as originally written; it's the cosines that we need to multiply by on the backward pass.

Here's an example:

```python
## print_fwd_bwd

from jax.tree_util import tree_flatten, tree_unflatten

from rich.console import Console
from rich.table import Table
import rich.text

def print_fwd_bwd(f, *args, **kwargs) -> None:
  args, in_tree = tree_flatten((args, kwargs))

  def f_(*args):
    args, kwargs = tree_unflatten(in_tree, args)
    return f(*args, **kwargs)

  fwd = jax.make_jaxpr(lambda *args: jax.vjp(f_, *args))(*args).jaxpr

  y, f_vjp = jax.vjp(f_, *args)
  res, in_tree = tree_flatten(f_vjp)

  def g_(*args):
    *res, y = args
    f_vjp = tree_unflatten(in_tree, res)
    return f_vjp(y)

  bwd = jax.make_jaxpr(g_)(*res, y).jaxpr

  table = Table(show_header=False, show_lines=True, padding=(1, 2, 0, 2), box=None)
  table.add_row("[bold green]forward computation:",
                "[bold green]backward computation:")
  table.add_row(rich.text.Text.from_ansi(str(fwd)),
                rich.text.Text.from_ansi(str(bwd)))
  console = Console(width=240)
  console.print(table)

## example

import jax
import jax.numpy as jnp

def f(x):
  return jnp.sin(jnp.sin(x))

print_fwd_bwd(f, 1.0)

#   forward computation:       backward computation:
#›
#   { lambda ; a:f32[]. let    { lambda ; a:f32[] b:f32[] c:f32[]. let
#       b:f32[] = sin a            d:f32[] = mul c b
#       c:f32[] = cos a            e:f32[] = mul d a
#       d:f32[] = sin b          in (e,) }
#       e:f32[] = cos b
#     in (d, c, e) }
```
- mattjj commented on 2024-06-24T23:13:47Z: It's probably not clear from the way that prints but the latter two outputs of the forward computation (namely `c` and `e`) get passed to the first two outputs of the backward computation (namely `a` and `b`).

- jakevdp commented on 2024-04-25T23:05:51Z: I don't think this change is necessary: the array API specifies that the arguments to `tile` are passed by position. `jnp.tile` accept arguments passed by position, thus we support specification-compatible calls to the function without any changes to the code. Yes, we also support arguments passed by keyword, but that doesn't conflict with the specification.

Deprecations are painful for users, and we should avoid them unless they are absolutely necessary. As long as JAX provides a superset of the specification API, we should not make changes.

What do you think?
