- chaserileyroberts commented on 2023-10-24T16:53:48Z: > Why is the jaxpr the right thing to pickle?

Because my goal is to be able to transform `f` _before_ sending it off to the workers. I can not do that with just the original definition of `f` unless I do that transform instead on every single worker, which is not scalable for my goals. 
- chaserileyroberts commented on 2023-10-24T16:55:53Z: > which is not scalable for my goals.

For example: if my transform is a randomized optimization, I would need to ensure all of the workers came to the exact same solution. Possible, but incredibly fragile. Solving this first on the client before dispatching prevents this issue forever. 
- chaserileyroberts commented on 2023-10-24T17:47:40Z: I want jaxprs to be able to be passed around, modified, and executed using standard distributed python tooling. This could have a wide range of applications beyond just pickling `jit(f)`

You could imagine the jaxprs being used with a Ray / Dask server just for the _compiler optimization_ and not even the actual execution. Something like:

```python
# Use the remote cluster to optimize your jaxpr.
jxpr = best_of([optimize.remote(f, seed) for seed in initial_seeds], my_metrics)

# Execute the jaxpr locally on your GPU.
jax.jit(jaxpr_as_fun(jxpr))(my_args)
```
- froystig commented on 2023-10-24T22:45:30Z: I think we can imagine similar such things (in fact, @mattjj had a branch doing something similar for a Ray prototype a while back, though we never merged it). While we all broadly agree that this can be potentially useful, it's not free, hence the questions about alternatives. For your immediate, concrete use case, does pickling `jit(f)` suffice? Could you do anything else short of pickling jaxpr?
- chaserileyroberts commented on 2023-10-25T00:03:21Z: >  For your immediate, concrete use case, does pickling jit(f) suffice?

Sadly not really, I've tried and it's usually pretty painful.

> Could you do anything else short of pickling jaxpr?

This is the setup I want to solve: I have a jax function, `f`, and I have a transform `trfm`, which can be expensive, and possibly non deterministic. I want to execute `trfm(f)(args...)` in an SPMD fashion on a distributed `mesh`

I've come up with several ideas to do this

1. Make all of the transforms execute on the workers. 
     * This is what is recommended currently in JAX.
     * This is reasonable for well-defined, deterministic transforms (i.e., `grad, vmap, vjp`), but can become difficult if `trfm` needs to do expensive optimization searches, or if any randomization is used. 
     * When developers create their own custom transform as `jax.extend` evolves, they're going to have a bad time ~if~ when they need to debug a nondeterminism bug across a cluster. 

2. Make some kind of separate IR that is pickled instead of the `Jaxpr`s. 
    * I don't think anyone wants to support this lol. 

3. Support pickling `Jaxprs`. 
     * This PR. 
     * In this setup, our `Jaxpr` can be derived locally if `trfm` is randomized or complicated. We then dispatch this jaxpr with Ray or Dask (via cloudpickle) to the entire mesh. 
     * All nodes have the exact same `Jaxpr`, so when you run `jit(jaxpr_as_fun(jaxpr))(arg...)` on all nodes simultaneously, the chance of bugs related to nodes running mismatching SPMD binaries drops significantly. 

Honestly, these are the only solutions I could think of. I've had to both 1) and 2) at various times in the past and they always are very fragile. If instead I could have 3) JustWork™, it would significantly simplify a lot of the dispatching infrastructure for auto-partitioning work. 

There could be a forth even easier solution I am missing, but I haven't found it yet. Ideas are welcomed! 

>  While we all broadly agree that this can be potentially useful, it's not free, hence the questions about alternatives

Nothing is ever free, but what is the cost we're trying to avoid here? We have unit tests that will catch obvious problems quickly, and I am happy to be the one responsible to fix issues related to this (I'll probably be the one hitting issues the most anyway lol). 

I can see the argument against adding another global dictionary to manage, but we already use similar global dictionaries for `vmap`, `jit`, `grad`, and well, basically everything! It's not a weird thing to see in the JAX codebase. 

I can also see an argument against the name strings being used for infrastructure. I also don't like this either, but the inclusion of `namespace` and possibly also including the `jax.__version__` (I should add this...), should be enough to avoid conflicts/compatibility issues.  There are no name conflicts as it stands today (at least in OSS land), and again issues could likely be caught quickly with good unit tests.

So the cost is: 
* Manage 40 new LOC, a single extra global dictionary, and a few unit tests. 
* Risk that we add new attributes that are not pickleable in the future and have to deal with them. 
  * Unit tests will likely catch it, and you can `None` them out in a `__reduce_ex__` method like I did with `Traceback`. Annoying but not terrible. 

The value: 
* Ray and Dask are automatically fully compatible with Jaxprs. 
* Unlocks distributed jaxpr optimizations and dispatch.

In my opinion it's super worth it.

Pull Request 17658 titled '[jax2tf] Use functools.wraps to ensure jax2tf.convert preserves inspect.signature' was created by gnecula (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- gnecula commented on 2023-09-19T09:48:48Z: @maxwillzq PTAL
- gnecula commented on 2023-09-20T15:24:01Z: I thought that this would be an easy change, but it is breaking tests and some of the breakages are hard to debug. So far I debugged this:

```
def f_jax(x, flag=True):
  return jnp.sin(x) if flag else jnp.cos(x)

tf.function(jax2tf.convert(f_jax))(0.7)
```

In the above code `tf.function` will try to be smart and see the default value of `flag=True` and invoke `jax2tf.convert` not with just one positional argument but also with `flag=True`, which will make the JAX machinery use a tracer for the value of `flag`, which will fail with a concretization error in `if flag`. The workaround is to explicitly hide the default parameter to `f_jax`:

```
tf.function(jax2tf.convert(lambda x: f_jax(x)))(0.7)
```

This also comes up with things like `jax2tf.convert(jnp.sum)` because `jnp.sum` takes several default arguments that cannot be tracers.

(This is starting to make me wonder if this change is worth having. It is pretty hard to debug the issue above, and the error looks like a jax2tf one, with an exception thrown from JAX, even though the issue is with `tf.function` having too much magic.)

- maxwillzq commented on 2023-09-20T17:13:42Z: Can `autograph=False` of `tf.function` fix this problem on those failed test ? Because `autograph=True` will replace the python 'if' to `tf.if` op.  So it can preserve data dependent control flow.
 
- gnecula commented on 2023-09-21T14:38:16Z: `autograph=False` will not solve the problem, because it would try to trace through all the control flow in `jax2tf` itself.

Plus there are other instances when such default arguments need to be treated as static, e.g., when they are used to compute shapes.

Comments:
- yashk2810 commented on 2023-06-21T21:25:41Z: Hey @jakevdp, is this the recommended practice for other APIs in JAX too?

Will this break a bunch of stuff? Is there a flag that the user can set which would give them this behavior?
- yashk2810 commented on 2023-06-23T05:31:45Z: Looking at this more closely, I think this is intended because you are setting the x64 flag to True so things will get promoted. I think this is WAI.
- jakevdp commented on 2023-06-23T07:38:53Z: It's intended that `int32` gets cast to `int64` in summation aggregates. This was baked-in to `jax.numpy.sum` very early, because it's what `numpy.sum` does. We looked at changing that a while ago (the `promote_integers` argument was something I added as an intended backward-compatibilty shim after we had decided to do this), but midway through the planned change there was a lot of pushback because it introduced the possibility of silent integer overflows in some cases (integer overflows are already a danger for other integer operations virtually everywhere already, but I digress)

Whether it makes sense that `broadcast_one_to_all` calls `jnp.sum` directly and inherits its dtype behavior is less clear to me.

I don't think that this PR should be merged as-is, though: it would be confusing if `psum` had different type semantics from `sum`. Perhaps `psum` should gain a `promote_integers` argument? And perhaps `broadcast_one_to_all` should have different dtype semantics than `sum`? I'm not sure.
- inailuig commented on 2023-06-23T07:43:42Z: 


> Looking at this more closely, I think this is intended because you are setting the x64 flag to True so things will get promoted. I think this is WAI.

Sorry, I think I my initial example was not clear enough (simplified too much), here is the reproducer for the actual bug I am trying to solve:

```python
import jax
import jax.numpy as jnp

jax.config.update("jax_enable_x64", True)

# even fails if we are not distributed
# jax.distributed.initialize(...)  

kx = jax.random.PRNGKey(0)
#print(jax.random.uniform(kx))

ky = jax.experimental.multihost_utils.broadcast_one_to_all(kx)
print(jax.random.uniform(ky))
```
which fails with the following error:
```
TypeError: JAX encountered invalid PRNG key data: expected key_data.dtype = uint32; got dtype=uint64

```

Feel free to close this PR, and let me know if I should open an issue instead, if that is easier for you.

- jakevdp commented on 2023-06-23T07:45:28Z: We should never be calling `jnp.sum` on PRNG Keys.

Yash – is it possible to implement `broadcast_one_to_all` without invoking summation? Why is summation necessary?
- jakevdp commented on 2023-06-23T08:28:37Z: Note that in the future, adding or summing PRNG keys will result in an error, because semantically PRNG keys do not support addition. (You can set `jax_enable_custom_prng=True` to see how this will manifest).

This tells me that either (1) `broadcast_one_to_all` is semantically incompatible with PRNG keys, or (2) `broadcast_one_to_all` does not require addition/summation of data.
- yashk2810 commented on 2023-06-23T13:53:11Z: Maybe broadcast_one_to_all is not the right solution for whatever you are trying to do. Can you please open a discussions topic and I can tag in relevant folks to help? Please explain what you are trying to do when you do open the discussions topic rather than just the error you are seeing. (maybe also close this PR?)

> broadcast_one_to_all does not require addition/summation of data.

No, that's not possible. We need to run a collective to all-reduce across all the hosts so that the broadcasting can happen.
- jakevdp commented on 2023-06-23T14:17:03Z: OK, then I think we can safely say that `broadcast_one_to_all` is not an appropriate operation for PRNG keys.
- inailuig commented on 2023-06-23T14:19:06Z: > Maybe broadcast_one_to_all is not the right solution for whatever you are trying to do. Can you please open a discussions topic and I can tag in relevant folks to help? Please explain what you are trying to do when you do open the discussions topic rather than just the error you are seeing. (maybe also close this PR?)


I realized that for my use-case I am better off broadcasting the seed, instead of the PRNGkey. There it is no problem if the type is promoted, therefore no further discussion will be needed.

I still think it is inconsistent if a broadcast function changes the type, but so be it.

Thanks for the help so far, I will close this PR.

- harryjulian commented on 2023-01-17T12:33:11Z: Been sitting on this for a little bit now, just wondering if you could offer some input!

I've done most of the re-factoring, but I'm unsure on the best way to work the conditional in with the new broadcasting. Here's the code-sample:

```
def vonmises(
  key: KeyArray,
  x: RealArray,
  kappa: RealArray,
  shape: Optional[Shape] = None,
  dtype: DTypeLikeFloat = dtypes.float_,
  max_iters: int = 100
) -> Array:
  """Draw samples from a von Mises distribution.

  Args:
    key: a PRNG key used as the random key.
    x: mean of the distribution. Must be broadcast-compatible with kappa.
    kappa: concentration of the distribution. Must be broadcast-comptible with x.
    shape: optional, shape of the output array.
    dtype: optional, dtype of the output array. (default float64 if
      jax_enable_x64 is true, otherwise float32).
    max_iters: maximum number of times to run the algorithm
      that generates and accepts/rejects samples.

  Returns:
    theta: A random array of specified shape and dtype.

  Reference:
    Best, D. J., & Fisher, N. I. (1979). Efficient Simulation of the
    von Mises Distribution. Applied Statistics, 28(2), 152.
    https://doi.org/10.2307/2346732
  """
  # Check Key, Dtypes, Shape
  key, _ = _check_prng_key(key)
  if not dtypes.issubdtype(dtype, np.floating):
    raise ValueError(f"dtype argument to `t` must be a float"
                     f"dtype, got {dtype}.")
  dtype = dtypes.canonicalize_dtype(dtype)
  
  if shape is None:
    shape = lax.broadcast_shapes(np.shape(x), np.shape(kappa))
  else:
    _check_shape("vonmises", shape, x, kappa)

  def _true(key: Array, x: Array, kappa: Array) -> Array:
    return jnp.pi * 2 * uniform(key, shape, dtype)

  def _false(key: Array, x: Array, kappa: Array)-> Array:
    return _vonmises(key, x, kappa, shape, dtype, 100)

  # Return Distribution
  return lax.cond(
    kappa < 1e-5, 
    lambda key, x, kappa: _true(key, x, kappa),
    lambda key, x, kappa: _false(key, x, kappa),
    key, x, kappa
  )
```

Unfortunately, `lax.select` doesn't play nicely with the` kappa < 1e-5` condition:

```
TypeError: Pred must be a scalar, got [[ True]
 [ True]
 [ True]
 [ True]
 [ True]
 [ True]
 [ True]
 [ True]
 [ True]
 [ True]] of shape (10, 1).
```
The problem is that, after broadcasting, for rows/columns where the corresponding value of kappa is below the threshold we want to apply the uniform approximation. Does lax.cond allow the activation of both conditions? Any ideas on best ways to overcome this?
- jakevdp commented on 2023-01-17T17:42:36Z: `lax.cond` requires a scalar condition. For a vector condition, you can use `lax.select`

import jax

Body: No description available

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2022-11-04T16:48:09Z: Good question - for repeated operations after the initial run, we get something like this:

main branch:
```python
In [2]: %timeit jax.block_until_ready(jnp.split(x, jnp.arange(0, 5000, 10)))                                          
40.5 ms ± 4.22 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)
```

this branch:
```python
In [2]: %timeit jax.block_until_ready(jnp.split(x, jnp.arange(0, 5000, 10)))                                          
116 ms ± 4.01 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)
```
So a slowdown of ~3x on repeated calls is the tradeoff for saving ~150x on the initial call.

What do you think?
- froystig commented on 2022-11-11T18:29:23Z: From conversation with @hawkinsp: we may want to profile in order to understand why the dynamic slice approach is 3x slower, since it isn't clear that it ought to be (?)
- KeAWang commented on 2022-12-08T08:19:23Z: Why is `dynamic_slice` faster than static `slice` in the first place?
- jakevdp commented on 2022-12-08T17:15:54Z: > Why is `dynamic_slice` faster than static `slice` in the first place?

`dynamic_slice` is slower than static `slice` if you call it once, because it does not specialize its code on index values, and so at runtime XLA has to perform some logic regarding the value of the start index. But static `slice` is specialized on static start indices, so each call with different start indices incurs a small overhead in XLA at compile time, and when you accumulate this small overhead thousands of times, it is slower than `dynamic_slice`, which does not have such overhead because it is not specialized on the index values.
- KeAWang commented on 2022-12-08T18:48:14Z: Thanks! That explains the performance issues I've been trying to debug with slice vs dynamic_slice vs numpy slice.
- jakevdp commented on 2023-11-03T20:27:24Z: I can no longer reproduce these performance issues, despite this still lowering to static slice.

Body: No description available

Comments:
- yashk2810 commented on 2022-09-22T00:45:33Z: This is already handled in lower_sharding_computation. Why do we need to handle it in pjit's dispatch path?
- yashk2810 commented on 2022-09-22T00:48:40Z: https://github.com/google/jax/blob/main/jax/interpreters/pxla.py#L2725-L2731 is the place where we DCE. What's the advantage of doing it in dispatch?
- yashk2810 commented on 2022-09-22T00:50:51Z: AFAIK, this is how DCE happens in jit too. `jit` never tries to DCE right at the start (feel free to correct me if that's not the case).

keep_unused is always set to True for pjit though: https://github.com/google/jax/blob/main/jax/experimental/pjit.py#L964 due to some failures that we encountered in deepmind and our own pjit tests IIRC.
- mattjj commented on 2022-09-22T03:49:13Z: Please note this is a draft PR, not marked ready for review! But I probably shouldn't have pre-added you as a reviewer as that was confusing.

> This is already handled in lower_sharding_computation. Why do we need to handle it in pjit's dispatch path?

Actually, we were operating under some faulty hypotheses about observed behavior, thinking that the DCE wasn't happening.

An advantage of this approach over doing it in `lower_sharding_computation` is that we do it early, so any passes on the jaxpr don't need to deal with dead code.

That said, I don't think that advantage alone is worth the upside.

> AFAIK, this is how DCE happens in jit too. jit never tries to DCE right at the start (feel free to correct me if that's not the case).

Well, `pjit` forms a jaxpr up front before any transformations (it's an "initial-style higher-order primitive"), whereas `jit` only forms a jaxpr after transformations. So if we wanted to do DCE as soon as possible, i.e. as soon as a jaxpr is available, we would do it in `pjit` as in this PR, whereas with `jit` we could only do it in the impl rule.

So in the future, `pip install jax==0.5.0` can pull in the right `jaxlib`, etc., but a user may end up `pip install jaxlib==0.3.0` for some reason and it will pass with that mild, nonfatal error printed above.

In summary, the more pieces that have to coexist within strict parameters, the more issues can potentially arise due to the lack of strictness in the pip resolution of packages. That's a downside of slicing packages and I assume that's why big packages tend to bundle all sorts of random things (e.g. have you seen what pytorch bundles? did you know scipy bundles its own version of openblas in the pip package? etc.) so that the failure points are minimized. I tend to argue against this type of thing because it is a pain in conda-forge, but I do realize the benefits of it and I am making an effort to be unbiased here :) 

--

I have no idea about commercial vs non-commercial nature of stuff, but conda-forge is super-strictly separate from anaconda (at least in my understanding) and they only host our packages on anaconda.org. NVIDIA publishes random things on conda-forge, as well as others, so I usually operate with the assumption that it is a very relaxed community with loose rules. I can probably get someone to weigh on better on this --- some of the core developers at conda-forge have financial ties with companies and they have some policies for these people. As a personal example, I have never personally used any of Anaconda's stuff, and I only use things through conda-forge (and I have no ties to Anaconda at all; I am just a random academic researcher who helps maintain some packages under conda-forge)

--

Hey! Check out mambaforge :) (mambaforge is miniforge but it comes preinstalled with the mamba solver, which is significantly faster --- and better! --- than the conda solver in miniforge; I believe sooner or later the mamba solver will be adopted into the conda solver though)

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2022-08-01T22:15:17Z: Thanks - I believe the documentation is correct as written. See the outputs here:
```python
>>> from jax import lax
>>> import numpy as np
>>> lax.linalg.eigh(np.eye(3))
(DeviceArray([[1., 0., 0.],
              [0., 1., 0.],
              [0., 0., 1.]], dtype=float32),
 DeviceArray([1., 1., 1.], dtype=float32))
```
The first returned element contains the eigenvectors `v`, while the second contains the eigenvalues `w`.

If you're looking for a function with a signature similar to `numpy.linalg.eigh`, you probably want [`jax.numpy.linalg.eigh`](https://jax.readthedocs.io/en/latest/_autosummary/jax.numpy.linalg.eigh.html).
- Sohl-Dickstein commented on 2022-08-02T00:35:18Z: Thanks for the careful consideration! And good catch. This is my bad -- I was running jax.numpy.linalg.eigh, but reading the documentation for lax.linalg.eigh. I saw the first was just a lightweight wrapper around the second, and somehow thought it also inherited its doc-string.

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2022-06-14T16:17:58Z: Hi - thanks for the PR! In the past when we've discussed the polynomial interface, we've made the choice to avoid adding polynomial class types in favor of the more direct functional API (e.g. https://github.com/google/jax/issues/70#issuecomment-907892885). One concern I have here is that when you start to define class-based interfaces, you have to be much more careful to ensure that they're compatible with JAX's transformation model.

Is there any functionality here that cannot be expressed directly via chebyshev functions, as opposed to a full chebyshev class?
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-14T16:31:46Z: I believe the Chebyshev functions capture all of the functionality, so getting rid of the full class shouldn't cause any problems and would honestly simplify the interface. Would you like me to remove it?
- jakevdp commented on 2022-06-14T16:39:39Z: I would lean toward keeping only the simplest functional APIs in JAX, partly because it makes long-term maintenance more sustainable (the class definition in this PR is a **gigantic** API surface to test and maintain). But I'm happy to let other team members weigh-in if they disagree.
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-14T19:15:49Z: Alright, I removed the Chebyshev class and its abstract base class to streamline the API. If it's decided later that they are worth including, I have local copies and can add them back in.
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-16T16:24:30Z: Alright, I've cleaned up a lot of the code following your suggestions and to better match the existing polynomial functions in JAX. I've also been thinking more about JAX compatibility, and I wanted to ask a couple questions. The object arrays and value-based shapes were unnecessary, but loop implementations are necessary (or at least the natural way to implement many functions) because of the relationships between terms in a Chebyshev series. 

So, what do you consider "large" for a series or loop parameter? If a typical series is large, would replacing Python control flow  with JAX control flow primitives resolve the incompatibility/inefficiency issues? If so, I will make those changes and then push everything.
- jakevdp commented on 2022-06-16T16:29:28Z: The issue with Python loops is that they are flattened by JAX tracing, and then passed in an unrolled state to the XLA compiler. The mechanics of the compiler are complicated, but a good rule of thumb is that compilation time will be roughly quadratic in the number of operations. So if you write a Python `for` loop over 100 elements, then compilation will be roughly 10000 times more costly than the equivalent `fori_loop` implementation. There's not really any hard line regarding what size the loops should be, but if you expect the functions to operate on larger inputs, it's something to keep in mind. Does that make sense?
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-16T16:32:29Z: Yes, that's very helpful, thank you!
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-20T19:41:28Z: Ok, I've removed all Python loops from chebyshev.py and replaced them with JAX control flow primitives. I've also cleaned up most of the functions to make them less convoluted where possible. Is there anything else you would like me to do?
Thank you!
- jakevdp commented on 2022-06-21T16:36:11Z: Thanks. Another big piece of adding this kind of functionality is testing – before we can merge this, we'll need full test coverage of the functionality. If it's helpful, you can base it off of existing tests in https://github.com/google/jax/blob/main/tests/polynomial_test.py. Let me know if you have questions about that!

Also, just FYI we have some work in progress that will add some constraints to this code (see #10840): essentially, JAX library code will no longer be able to rely on implicit dtype promotion once that is merged. You can run your tests locally with that condition by setting the flag value `JAX_NUMPY_DTYPE_PROMOTION=strict`
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-22T16:15:10Z: Alright, I have a couple questions. First of all, many NumPy Chebyshev functions trim trailing zeros before returning, a feature I omitted from the JAX versions for jit compatibility. When comparing against NumPy, should I just wrap JAX-based versions of these functions in a trimzeros function, or is there a better way to test that ignores length differences? 

Second, what is the desired behavior for functions under the new dtype promotion constraints? Should functions like chebadd raise an error if the input arrays have different dtypes, should they attempt explicit dtype promotion, or should they do something else?

Thank you!
- jakevdp commented on 2022-06-22T22:42:45Z: Excellent question - one strategy we typically use in this situation (where the numpy behavior is incompatible with JIT) is to add an additional keyword argument, set so that the default value matches the behavior of numpy, and so that it can be changed to modify the API to be compatible with JIT (you can see an example in the `strip_zeros` keyword to `jnp.roots`, which I just finished revamping in #11215)

I think you could use a very similar treatment here.

Regarding dtypes: the rule of thumb is that if a dtype mismatch comes from two arrays passed by the user, you should let the error through. If it comes from the implementation (e.g. you do something like `x + jnp.arange(x.shape[-1])` and it errors because `x` is float32) then you should adjust the implementation to be compatible with strict promotion. Does that make sense?
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-22T23:18:24Z: Yes, that all makes sense. Thank you!
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-24T15:20:45Z: I've finished writing the Chebyshev tests, and they can all pass - with some caveats. The output of some functions (chebpow, chebfit, chebval, chebroots) can have mismatched values further apart than the tolerance of 1e-6 that I've been using, especially for higher-order inputs. Are there ways to make JAX output better match NumPy output, or are those numerical differences unavoidable?

Second, some tests can also fail in cases where NumPy warns but still returns output matching the JAX output. How should I handle these cases?
- jakevdp commented on 2022-06-24T15:41:35Z: Regarding precision – I suspect this is due to JAX executing in float32, while numpy executes in float64. You can execute the tests with `JAX_ENABLE_X64=true` to get 64-bit execution

Regarding warnings - you can filter them if they're expected. You can see examples of this elsewhere in the tests, e.g. https://github.com/google/jax/blob/4c25ef1d0039ecdd517ce2b09605322797700c2a/tests/lax_numpy_test.py#L579-L584
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-27T16:13:32Z: Ok, all test pass with JAX_ENABLE_x64=true and JAX_NUMPY_DTYPE_PROMOTION=strict. I also updated applicable functions with a "trim" keyword argument so that they match NumPy behavior by default. What's the next step?
Thank you!
- gderossi commented on 2022-06-29T16:08:30Z: Implemented the changes you requested, and hopefully fixed what caused the chebcompanion test to fail last time.
- gderossi commented on 2022-07-11T16:03:41Z: Made the changes you requested. Also, the Chebyshev test suite takes 75-80 seconds to run on my laptop using the command you provided. 
- jakevdp commented on 2022-07-11T16:31:35Z: That's a bit concerning, to be quite honest: currently our CI jobs run in about 20-30 minutes, so this PR would be adding 3-5% testing overhead for a single new API. Our strategy for avoiding test timeouts is generally to reduce `NUM_GENERATED_CASES` globally once we start hitting timeout limits... I'm not sure it makes sense to reduce our package-wide test coverage by 5% in order to add a few chebyshev polynomial routines that probably only a handful of users will ever use.

This is a tricky one, I'm not sure what to recommend...
- gderossi commented on 2022-07-12T20:11:01Z: After some more testing, I believe the Chebyshev tests actually contribute a much smaller percentage of total testing time: I ran the full test suite on my laptop yesterday, and it took about 2 hours and 18 minutes, or ~8300 seconds. Running the Chebyshev test file individually took 75-80 seconds, which is 0.9-1% of the total. I just ran the test suite remotely on a much more powerful computer, which completed all the tests in 1270 seconds and the Chebyshev tests alone in 11 seconds, which is ~0.866% of the total.
I'm happy to repeat these tests or try other tests you think would be helpful to verify this ratio. 1% of the testing overhead is still significant, so I've also experimented with reducing the Chebyshev tests, as I noticed that polynomial_tests.py only includes tests for jnp.roots. 
Many of the cheb* functions call other cheb* functions - for example, chebpow calls chebadd, so the chebadd tests could potentially be removed. Changes that break chebadd would (hopefully) be caught by the chebpow tests. Another category of functions, the 2d and 3d versions of chebval/chebgrid/chebvander, are simply wrappers for nested calls of the respective 1d functions. Tests for these could also be removed, as the 1d function tests should cover everything.
Removing tests for all functions that fall under the two categories described above cuts the time of the Chebyshev tests in half, and a majority of this cost is due to only a few functions: chebfit, chebdiv, and chebfromroots. Reducing the number of test cases for these particular functions or eliminating tests for them entirely could significantly speed up the Chebyshev tests.

Thank you for your time, let me know what you think!
- jakevdp commented on 2022-07-18T20:46:43Z: Thanks - that makes sense. Let's go ahead and merge this and we can deal with any test timeout issues separately. Thanks for all the work here!
- jakevdp commented on 2022-07-18T21:26:38Z: The test failures here look real: it looks like `chebgrid` does some implicit type promotion when it is passed integer inputs.
- gderossi commented on 2022-07-18T22:21:31Z: Ok, should be fixed now. All tests are passing locally for every combination of  JAX_ENABLE_X64 and JAX_NUMPY_DTYPE_PROMOTION.

Comments:
- nicholasjng commented on 2022-06-03T14:50:16Z: Putting this up as a draft first, please do comment / give your thoughts to influence direction.

Modules that were not ported yet (all due to the use of `vlog_is_on`, `vlog` from absl logging):

- [x] `jax.experimental.compilation_cache` 
- [x] `jax.experimental.host_callback`
- [x] `jax.interpreters.pxla`
- [x] `jax.interpreters.sharded_jit`
- [x] `jax._src.lib.xla_bridge`

~I am not sure how to replace them, it is definitely not possible with imports only. `absl` implements some APIs that allow treatment of the log level as a module-wide attribute, since the logger is a singleton there, while Python builtin logging puts the log level as a Logger attribute. How should this work here? I think the answer will depend on how customizable JAX's logging is supposed to be in the end, for example if logfile writes could be an option in the future for computation runs. Happy to hear your thoughts - especially on the general direction of the implementation here.~

EDIT: I implemented `jax.logging.vlog` as a cross-platform API. This is ready for review

- nicholasjng commented on 2022-09-28T13:30:03Z: Rebased on main and deleted the jax2tf material, not sure how it ended up there.
- nicholasjng commented on 2022-10-01T14:33:31Z: Thank you for the feedback!

> It seems to me that this is behavior we'd rather avoid, although I'm not entirely certain. What do you think?

Definitely to be avoided, in my opinion. I was unaware of this, but I could see that symbols taken from an imported module are not updated upon module reload. The other option, only ever using the `jax.logging` import and never any function-level imports from it, seems like a pretty big restriction on the user to me.

> If we wanted to, could we change the implementation to make this behave analogously to your initial example (namely, respecting the dynamic change in config setting)?

Judging from browsing SO on Python hot reloading for a couple of minutes, the logging member imports in the caller module need to be reloaded as well. I do not exactly know if/how that is possible, but the machinery probably exists. My guess is it would most likely be the current solution plus a lookup of any imported `jax.logging` module members in the "right place" (where exactly is TBD), and, if found, their reimport.

For your reference: A good SO thread I found on this (because of an illustrative code example) is [this one](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/1739924/python-reload-component-y-imported-with-from-x-import-y); the example from the Python REPL there indicates the difference between whole-module imports and "dotted" (module member) imports, where the latter requires the second `from X import Y` statement for a successful reload.

So if we find a way to emulate the second import statement from the config update hook, we should be good to go.
- froystig commented on 2022-10-03T20:27:51Z: Also for reference, based on a quick test, [PEP 562](https://peps.python.org/pep-0562/) (`__getattr__` on modules) will not help us here either.

We should be able to handle all module-level functions, like `logging.warning`, by defining each one as a function that switches on the config setting to call the corresponding selected implementation (standard `warning` or absl `warning`). The remaining challenge is to handle the non-callable attributes. From what I can tell, all of these are logging level integers, such as `logging.DEBUG`.

Could we simply choose not to support the vlog parts of the logging interface (`vlog` and `vlog_is_on`), and instead maintain a habit of only calling `logging.info`, `logging.warning`, etc. directly?

@jakevdp @skye @hawkinsp any thoughts?
- froystig commented on 2022-10-04T19:55:36Z: Related discussion in #12651 
- nicholasjng commented on 2022-10-04T20:25:08Z: Cool. I initially even planned to do it this way, but I got discouraged by the boilerplate that this added for supporting the whole logging interface.
I also opted to keep the `vlog` usage to make the change less disruptive and allow smooth adoption, but I personally think the discussed `logging.debug/info/...` APIs should be plenty - happy to change that, after a quick discussion on what the `CPP_{WARNING,ERROR}` levels should become.

As for the integers, we _could_ just use `logging`'s version of the constants, and set up a level conversion mechanism for absl APIs similar to ABSL's internal conversion of levels in `absl.log`, where we need to. But are you sure that the `if` branch there does not suffice? (I thought it might end up working like a C++ preprocessor directive)
- froystig commented on 2022-10-10T23:55:31Z: I discussed this a bit with @hawkinsp and @shoyer. Now that we understand the costs better, we think it's worthwhile to simplify things and just drop absl logging altogether, rather than continue trying to support both logging packages via a common interface. To do that, we'll need to migrate the jax codebase further. And while we're at it, we should also avoid using the builtin `'root'` Python logger (cf. #12526). Here's how I suspect this could go:

1. Introduce a global internal logger instance, which we can name `'jax'`.
2. Since `vlog` will no longer be available, replace current uses of `vlog` with calls to the corresponding `logging.{debug,warning,info,...}` on the `'jax'` logger.
3. Similarly, replace current uses of `vlog_is_on` with equivalent logic from Python's `logging`, e.g. using [`isEnabledFor()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.Logger.isEnabledFor) and [`getEffectiveLevel()`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.Logger.getEffectiveLevel). Note that Python logging skips string interpolation if you format with positional arguments, so some current uses of `vlog_is_on` can maybe be removed entirely, if the interpolation cost is all that they are guarding. (See [here](https://docs.python.org/3/howto/logging.html#optimization) and [here](https://docs.python.org/3/howto/logging-cookbook.html#formatting-styles).)
4. Migrate `log` calls as well, so that we only use the `'jax'` non-root logger.
5. Drop `absl` logging entirely.

We would probably no longer need a `jax.logging` module. We could consider adding an internal `jax._src.logging` for any utilities that make things easier to manage, if the need for them arises while working on the changes above.

What do you think?

Of course, let us know if this seems like more than what you'd like to take on at this point, or if you'd like to handle only a subset of such changes in this PR.
- skye commented on 2022-10-11T00:08:11Z: Hey sorry for not responding earlier! The key thing I like about vlog is that you can specify a vmodule to only print vlogs from a certain file. This is way better than printing all debug logging, which is often way too verbose. vlog also has the feature of introducing arbitrary debug levels, so you can control the verbosity even within a file. This is pretty useful as well, but not as critical as the per-module logging IMO.

It sounds like we should be able to do this with Python logging as well though? Maybe by specifying a different logger for each file/module? I'm in general in favor of dropping absl logging because it barely works in Python (e.g. I only know how to set a Python vmodule when running inside Google).
- froystig commented on 2022-10-11T00:59:21Z: I was thinking that we can look into introducing more fine-grained loggers after we migrate (e.g. one per file or module, etc.). That way we keep things simple for a transition PR and then experiment with further changes afterwards (also e.g. trying custom formatters).

We might have to write a bit of code to reinstate a few absl-like behaviors that we like, but it seems that would still be the preferred eventual situation.
- hawkinsp commented on 2022-10-11T01:09:07Z: @skye The idiom that a lot of folks seem to use is:

```
import logging
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)

logger.debug("hello")
```

This plays a role similar to `vlog` and `vmodule`, because in another file you can turn up the verbosity of that specific module's logs like this:
```
import logging
l = logging.getLogger("jax.core")
l.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
```
i.e., you can enable debug logs on a per-module basis.

I would probably migrate the `vlog` uses to use that idiom right now.
- nicholasjng commented on 2022-10-11T06:41:45Z: Sounds good! I'll work on implementing your list when I get time, I expect it could work out this week.

As for the vlog/vmodule substitution, I think I will go with @hawkinsp's suggestion, and then make a global `jax` logger available somewhere.

By the way, would you support dropping `absl-py` as a package install requirement? It can probably stay for testing, but I think there was some interest for eliminating that dependency (ping @josephrocca).
- froystig commented on 2022-10-11T16:12:40Z: > As for the vlog/vmodule substitution, I think I will go with @hawkinsp's suggestion, and then make a global `jax` logger available somewhere.

Sounds good. Do we need both? What would the global `'jax'` logger be used for at that point?

> By the way, would you support dropping `absl-py` as a package install requirement? It can probably stay for testing, but I think there was some interest for eliminating that dependency (ping @josephrocca).

Yes, good idea. We still support [absl flags](https://github.com/google/jax/blob/05faf0f40d376afccd9c3e957fe811b4c839aed5/jax/_src/config.py#L137) optionally, but we can make this a soft dependency: works if absl is installed, doesn't otherwise.

Our tests use it, but it doesn't need to be an install requirement for jax. We may need to add it to [build/test-requirements.txt](https://github.com/google/jax/blob/main/build/test-requirements.txt).
- nicholasjng commented on 2022-10-11T16:19:49Z: Sweet. Then I am good to go, except for one proposal. What do you think about adding a small `get_logger` facility in, say, the top-level `jax` namespace? Makes for easy-to-remember code (think `logger = jax.get_logger(...)`, similar to @hawkinsp's example up top), and, maybe even nicer, would allow for some default values controllable by environment variables. 

I have a quick example [here](https://github.com/nicholasjng/pybm/blob/master/pybm/logging.py) from a personal project of mine; the `config.get_value(foo)` calls there could be `FLAGS.foo` for some newly added options (e.g. logfile, loglevel etc) in the JAX setting.

And last but not least, in that case, the proposed "jax" logger would be equal to the module-level logger for the `jax` top-level namespace, so the module-level solution is a perfect superset of the global one. 
- froystig commented on 2022-10-11T21:37:09Z: > What do you think about adding a small `get_logger` facility in, say, the top-level `jax` namespace? Makes for easy-to-remember code (think `logger = jax.get_logger(...)`, similar to @hawkinsp's example up top), and, maybe even nicer, would allow for some default values controllable by environment variables.

Do you mean to add it to the public `jax` namespace? Useful utilities are a fine idea in general. If I understood correctly, `get_logger` could be internal and go under `jax._src`, either in a new module like `jax._src.logging` or in an existing one like `jax._src.util`. (?)
- nicholasjng commented on 2022-10-14T06:53:24Z: Closing, as #12769 got accepted. Thanks for your input!

- oliverdutton commented on 2022-05-16T08:10:03Z: ### Abbreviated view
Gather/Scatter may have poor support/poor implementations on some hardware backends/converters e.g. jax2tf no XLA which is commonly used to export to ONNX or tflite. 

Looking at some ways Jax can be used:
| Conversion path | Exit point | Passes applied |
| ------------- | ------------- | ------------- |
| jax2tf  | jaxpr  | No simplifications |
| tflite.experimental_from_jax  | HLO  | gather pass (presumably as its platform independent) |
| Directly used  | optimised HLO  | scatter pass  (as platform dependent) |

This PR reimplements the scatter/gather passes at the jaxpr level. This is not a good general idea as in some cases it will backfire and lead to poor performance, but would help jax2tf. As for tflite, tflite.experimental_from_jax should just apply the optimisation pass to simplify scatters (I will add this as a separate issue). 

I think this pull request should only apply to jax2tf (I'll make the necessary code changes) and only when `enable_xla=False` is enabled. This flag suggests the exit point will not be XLA compiled and hence these simplifications improve support and probably performance.
- oliverdutton commented on 2022-05-16T22:13:18Z: This is now a companion PR request to #10653. But instead of mapping scatter to tf-scatter ops as the other PR does, this one expands them into slices. 

It covers a subset of the cases that #10653 does so I'm aiming to land both.

I've also placed the expanded gather, which may be replicating some of the rules already implemented.

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2022-02-24T18:13:18Z: Hi - thanks for looking into this. Improving JAX trace times is a great goal! That said, at first blush, I'm not convinced that microbenchmarks at this level are the best way to approach reducing JAX's overhead. Yes it's a ~30% improvement in runtime, but that improvement amounts to ~30µs per run when parsing 1000 static and 1000 dynamic indices, which I suspect is far more than are ever parsed in practice. If we assume the savings is linear in the number of parsed indices, then I expect the typical savings for a real use-case would be perhaps tens of nanoseconds for a typical gather operation. That's not zero, but I don't think it's something worth dwelling on in the overall computational cost of executing a JAX program.

Now I may be wrong... it would be interesting to see a line profiler output of a typical JAX computation, and see which operations are contributing the most. If `_merge_static_and_dynamic_indices` is high in that, then this may be a good change to consider.

By "favor writing algorithms for trees" did you mean to say "favor writing algorithms for vectors"?

Writing algorithms for vectors would definitely be my favored approach. Code for vectors is much more readable than code for pytrees (mostly due to support for infix arithmetic). When transformed with `tree_math` it will work for pytrees, too, and under `jit` performance should be identical to writing the transformations by hand.

- Edenhofer commented on 2021-11-19T22:21:16Z: Sorry for the noise! I was too hasty when looking at the implementation :|
I think an alias would be nice but I don't have any strong feelings about any of the two options.
- Edenhofer commented on 2021-11-23T15:30:42Z: I hope this comment is more qualified than my last one :|

I basically built a very similar class a while ago and happened to find the following convenience methods quite useful. Both method names also exist in numpy and these functions are straight-forward extensions of numpy-methods to pytreees.
```python
def size(tree, axis: Optional[int] = None) -> Union[int, jnp.ndarray]:
    if axis is not None:
        raise TypeError("axis of an arbitrary tree is ill defined")
    sizes = tree_map(jnp.size, tree)
    return tree_reduce(jnp.add, sizes)


def norm(tree, ord, *, ravel: bool = True):
    from jax.numpy.linalg import norm

    if ravel:

        def el_norm(x):
            return jnp.abs(x) if jnp.ndim(x) == 0 else norm(x.ravel(), ord=ord)
    else:

        def el_norm(x):
            return jnp.abs(x) if jnp.ndim(x) == 0 else norm(x, ord=ord)

    return norm(tree_leaves(tree_map(el_norm, tree)), ord=ord)
```

Note, `size` does the same thing as `Vector.__len__` (using `np.size(x) = np.prod(np.shape(x))`) but I prefer to use the former since `assert size(Vector(x)) == size(x)` would hold for any tensor while `assert len(Vector(x)) != len(x)`. In your implementation this is of course intentional. However, I find that I almost never want the length of the first axis and instead need the number of elements in the tensor so I use `size` for tensors and pytrees alike.

On a related note, I also overload `__getitem__` and `__contains__`. I use these helper methods to e.g. access elements of a math-enabled dictionary but really anything would work as long as `Vector._tree` implements these methods.

Surely not all helper methods are worth having upstream, but since JAX is experimenting with enabling numerics for pytrees, I though I would share these. I assume overloading `__getitem__` and `__contains__` is a bit too specific to my use case but maybe others might find these methods useful as well.

EDIT: `Vector.dot` is also one of those methods which I found convenient to have. It as well is part of the numpy.ndarray API and thus works for tensors and `Vector`s alike.
- shoyer commented on 2021-11-23T16:19:24Z: I'll add a `size` property and `dot` method, those are basically aliases for existing functionality.

I'm not sure `__getitem__` makes sense. Indexing like `x[y]` on a vector `x` could only work when the indexing object `y` is a Python integer:
- There's no unambiguous way to know the underlying pytree structure for slicing like `x[:3]`.
- Indexing with a JAX tracer doesn't work, because we need to know which array is being indexed from Python to generate do efficient indexing. This means we couldn't looping over an index variable, e.g., with `lax.fori_loop`.
- This leaves indexing like `x[0]` or `x[-1]`. I can see this being handy for debugging, but I can also see it misleadingly suggesting that general purpose indexing work.

I'm not sure what you're using `__contains__` for, but generally that overload does not make sense on multi-dimensional arrays. It also needs to return a Python builtin `bool`, which is rather restrictive. JAX does not implement it on its other array types and so I doubt it makes sense here, either.
- Edenhofer commented on 2021-11-23T17:31:00Z: Great, thanks!

Is `norm` also of interest or is it already too specific? It comes in handy for implementing convergence criteria in some minimization schemes which use e.g. the 1-norm or allow the user to set the order of the norm freely.

Sure, in general slicing does not work nor would a loop over all elements work efficiently. However, I don't use it for that. Most of the thinks I wrap end up being nested dictionaries of some sort and I forward `__contains__` and `__getitem__` on to the underlying object. Thus, `math_enabled_dict[some_key]` still accesses the underlying dictionary and yields whatever is at `some_key`.

My philosophy behind this decision was that whatever I wrap in a math-enabled pytree should still behave and act exactly as the un-wrapped object with the only constrain being that whatever method I implemented must also work for numpy arrays. For my implementation this means that `Vector(some_jnp_array)` behaves exactly the same as its un-wrapper counterpart. This might be overly specific to my use-case and might not fit the here-proposed `Vector` class. If so, feel free to disregard my comments on this topic.


>  JAX does not implement it on its other array types and so I doubt it makes sense here, either.

I am not sure what you mean by this; `assert 3 in jnp.arange(4)`  does work.
- shoyer commented on 2021-11-23T17:43:19Z: > Is `norm` also of interest or is it already too specific? It comes in handy for implementing convergence criteria in some minimization schemes which use e.g. the 1-norm or allow the user to set the order of the norm freely.

`norm` is not a method on numpy arrays. My current approach is that the functionality of `tree_math.Vector` should be a strict subset of the functionality of normal JAX/NumPy arrays.

Instead you could use infix arithmetic like `(x @ x) ** 0.5`.

> Sure, in general slicing does not work nor would a loop over all elements work efficiently. However, I don't use it for that. Most of the thinks I wrap end up being nested dictionaries of some sort and I forward `__contains__` and `__getitem__` on to the underlying object. Thus, `math_enabled_dict[some_key]` still accesses the underlying dictionary and yields whatever is at `some_key`.

Ah, I see. I'd like tree_math to be entirely explicit, and _strictly_ allow for manipulating pytrees as if they were 1D NumPy arrays. If you want to do this sort of access, you can pull out the underlying Pytree with the `.tree` attribute and then make a new `Vector`.

> > JAX does not implement it on its other array types and so I doubt it makes sense here, either.
> 
> I am not sure what you mean by this; `assert 3 in jnp.arange(4)` does work.

This is Python's fallback implementation of `__contains__`, via iteration with `__iter__`: https://docs.python.org/3/reference/datamodel.html#object.__contains__

We could certainly support `__iter__` on `tree_math.Vector`. It won't be very efficient, but I guess not much worse than iterating over normal JAX arrays.
- Edenhofer commented on 2021-11-23T18:16:06Z: > `norm` is not a method on numpy arrays. My current approach is that the functionality of `tree_math.Vector` should be a strict subset of the functionality of normal JAX/NumPy arrays.

Right, I got that from your implementation. Just to be clear, my proposal was to add `norm` as an additional function to `experimental.tree_math` in the same way `matmul` is exposed as function as well.

I think you also misunderstood this aspect of the proposed `size` function. Of course having it as a method of `Vector` works too but I think it would also be a great addition to `experimental.tree_math`. Similar to `matmul`, `size` and `norm` both make sense for general pytrees.

> Instead you could use infix arithmetic like (x @ x) ** 0.5.

Sure, I can of course implement any desired p-norm by hand but I find `norm(x, ord=p)` to be more convenient.

> This is Python's fallback implementation of __contains__, via iteration with __iter__: https://docs.python.org/3/reference/datamodel.html#object.__contains__

Ah, I see. Thank for the explanation!
- shoyer commented on 2021-11-23T18:29:49Z: > Similar to `matmul`, `size` and `norm` both make sense for general pytrees.

Just to be entirely clear, the functions implemented in tree_math don't work for general pytrees -- they only work for explicit `tree_math.Vector` objects. The only reason why I created `matmul` is that it gives a way to explicitly set the `precision` argument, which you can't do with infix notation. In general, I would rather encourage using methods than functions, because the methods will let you write portable code that also works on regular JAX arrays.

`norm` seems fine to add, but let's save that for a follow-on PR after this gets merged.
- Edenhofer commented on 2021-11-23T18:47:04Z: Ok. Thank you for all the explanations and of course for implementing it in the first place :)
- PhilipVinc commented on 2021-12-01T17:53:00Z: thanks!
- shoyer commented on 2021-12-29T00:57:40Z: We decided to implement this as a separate library outside of JAX for now. Please take a look https://github.com/google/tree-math/ !

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2021-05-11T00:01:57Z: Thanks for looking at this – I think in general we indend that anything annotated `jnp.ndarray` also accepts `np.ndarray`, but not vice-versa; you can see this via `isinstance` checks:
```python
>>> import numpy as np
>>> import jax.numpy as jnp
>>> isinstance(np.ones(4), jnp.ndarray)
True
>>> isinstance(jnp.ones(4), np.ndarray)
False
```
Given this, I think that for functions that accept both numpy and jax.numpy arrays as input `jnp.array` is the right type annotation.

Caveat: array annotations in general currently have very poor support in mypy & pytype; this is why in most places you'll see us annotate array inpyts with `Array` which is aliased to `Any`.
- NeilGirdhar commented on 2021-05-11T00:11:23Z: @jakevdp Thanks for the quick reply.  Those `isinstance` checks look great, but why doesn't `issubclass` work the same way?
```python
In [4]: issubclass(jnp.ndarray, np.ndarray)
Out[4]: True

In [5]: issubclass(np.ndarray, jnp.ndarray)
Out[5]: False
```
This is what MyPy sees:
```python
import jax.numpy as jnp
import numpy as np

z = np.zeros(4)

def f(x: jnp.ndarray) -> jnp.ndarray:
    return x

f(z)  # error: Argument 1 to "f" has incompatible type "numpy.ndarray"; expected "jax._src.numpy.lax_numpy.ndarray"
```
This works fine if we do it the other way around.  Is there a way to repair this so that it works the way you want it to with `jnp.ndarray` being the broader type?

(I'm happy to close the pull request and turn this into an issue if that's better?)
- jakevdp commented on 2021-05-11T01:49:02Z: Ah, I see. There's also the issue that when tracing functions, jax passes `Tracer` objects in place of arrays, so the `np.ndarray` type will fail there I suspect. We've not yet landed on any way to have meaningful mypy-compatible type annotations for traceable arguements to JAX functions.

If you want to fix this, I'd suggest doing what we do elsewhere: set `Array = Any` and annotate it with type `Array`. This is useful for people reading & understanding the source code, and mypy will never complain :grin:
- NeilGirdhar commented on 2021-05-11T04:54:04Z: @jakevdp Okay, sounds great!  Would it be possible to change these three `jnp.ndarray` to `Array` (`Any`) so that MyPy doesn't complain in the mean time?

Comments:
- jakevdp commented on 2021-04-30T19:50:09Z: Thanks – I think the reason this has not been implemented yet is that this function's semantics are fundamentally incompatible with JAX transforms, because the dtype of the return value depends on the values in the array.

I think we should avoid adding implementations of functions to `jax.numpy` that cannot be used in JIT or grad or vmap... I think the only option then would be to unconditionally return complex values, but zero-out the imaginary part if it's small. That departs from numpy's behavior (and arguably from the intent of the function), but it would then be compatible with JAX transforms. What do you think?
- lgeiger commented on 2021-04-30T23:15:39Z: That is a fair point. I don't see any way of easily solving this since XLA requires matching dtypes in control flow.

> I think the only option then would be to unconditionally return complex values, but zero-out the imaginary part if it's small. That departs from numpy's behavior (and arguably from the intent of the function), but it would then be compatible with JAX transforms. What do you think?

I think this would be a sensible behaviour. But ultimately I agree that the function with this behaviour would not be very useful in practice.

So I think the best way would probably to throw in cases where the functions is jited, or to just keep it unimplemented. Thinking about this again, I'd personally be in favour of closing this PR unless someone has a strong use case for this function.
- jakevdp commented on 2021-04-30T23:20:40Z: Makes sense - thanks for looking into this!

Pybind11 converts py::list (i.e. Python lists) into std::vector, and the other way around.

Tuples (py::tuple) are not convertible to std::vector (I imagine they are to std::tuple).

So if you pass a tuple to a function that expects a std::vector in C++, it will fail.

Pull Request 5075 titled 'Ensure lax.convert_element_type preserves concrete inputs' was created by jakevdp (User). The PR is in closed state. The PR contains N/A commits, with 0 additions and 0 deletions across 0 files. 

Body: No description available

Comments:
- mattjj commented on 2020-12-02T00:47:17Z: Interesting!

> There are several places in the JAX library where it is implicitly assumed that lax.convert_element_type will return concrete results for concrete inputs

 Could you unpack this more? That is, maybe these implicit assumptions are wrong, and we should be revising those places rather than revising convert_element_type.
- jakevdp commented on 2020-12-02T00:53:08Z: So I'm not sure about all the places this might arise, but any time we call utilities like `_promote_args`, it will call `lax.convert_element_type()` under the hood, and currently this will turn static dtype instances into dynamic traced values, which may break the assumptions in the code.

Before omnistaging, this was not the case: convert_element_type would not be staged when applied to static values.

With omnistaging, that broke in rare cases that happen to not be well covered in our test suite, so we didn't notice.

I came across this bug when refactoring `lax.convert_element_type` in a way that broke this assumption further, and it caused a number of test failures due to staging type conversions for concrete values.

I think the right way to go here is to restore the pre-omnistaging behavior, so that we can safely use `lax.convert_element_type` and utilities like `_promote_args` without having to consider whether the inputs are static.

What do you think?
- jakevdp commented on 2020-12-11T22:04:33Z: I'm going to close this because it's not clear that we want to always stage `lax.convert_element_type`.

Comments:
- shoyer commented on 2020-10-07T04:52:45Z: We _could_ do this, but I would lean towards preserving NumPy's interface for `matmul` and leaving advanced manipulations like this to `einsum` (which lowers to a mix of `dot_general` and `transpose`).

Unfortunately `einsum` doesn't do the desired thing here -- instead it adds another transpose afterwards:
```
>>> jax.make_jaxpr(lambda a, b: jnp.einsum('ij,kj->ik', a, b))(a, b)
{ lambda  ; a b.
  let c = xla_call[ backend=None
                    call_jaxpr={ lambda  ; a b.
                                 let c = dot_general[ dimension_numbers=(((1,), (1,)), ((), ()))
                                                      precision=None ] b a
                                     d = transpose[ permutation=(1, 0) ] c
                                 in (d,) }
                    device=None
                    donated_invars=(False, False)
                    name=_einsum ] a b
  in (c,) }
```

This could possibly be improved with some digging, however.
- antoniojkim commented on 2020-10-07T13:28:16Z: @shoyer Adding the optional transpose functionality does to a certain degree preserve the NumPy interface as all new arguments have default values and were positionally added to the end. No previous usages of the `matmul` function would have to change. Only going forward, the user would have slightly more control over the contraction dimensions than before. The motivation for doing this obviously would be that TensorFlow exposes this functionality in it's [`matmul`](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/linalg/matmul) function.

I still think it's a good idea to do this. What are your thoughts?
- hawkinsp commented on 2020-10-07T14:56:36Z: Another reason that it doesn't necessarily make sense to add functionality like `transpose` to `matmul` is that in JAX you have the freedom to form these kinds of composite ops using `jit`.

e.g., you can easily write things like

```
my_matmul = jax.jit(lambda x, y: x @ y.T)
```

I don't think "fewer instructions" is necessarily a good metric for better or worse code; under a `jit`, XLA will perform whole-program optimizations, and it may end up fusing the transpose with the dot anyway.
- antoniojkim commented on 2020-10-07T15:26:17Z: @hawkinsp its not about fewer instructions per-say. It's about performance. I submitted the PR because I found the change to have quite a bit of performance impact with large matrices. Sometimes the `jax.jit` operator does not optimize these out enough. e.g.

```python
>>> a = np.random.random((7, 2, 3))
>>> b = np.random.random((7, 2, 3))
>>> my_matmul = jax.jit(lambda x, y: jnp.matmul(x, jnp.transpose(y, [0, 2, 1])))
>>> jax.make_jaxpr(my_matmul)(a, b)
{ lambda  ; a b.
  let c = xla_call[ backend=None
                    call_jaxpr={ lambda  ; a b.
                                 let c = transpose[ permutation=(0, 2, 1) ] b
                                     d = dot_general[ dimension_numbers=(((2,), (1,)), ((0,), (0,)))
                                                      precision=None ] a c
                                 in (d,) }
                    device=None
                    donated_invars=(False, False)
                    name=<lambda> ] a b
  in (c,) }
```

Clearly, the jit did not optimize out the transpose in favour of changing the `dot_general` contraction dimensions. The additional explicit transpose can have performance implications, especially if the transposed matrix multiplication is used frequently and on large matrices.

> XLA will perform whole-program optimizations, and it may end up fusing the transpose with the dot anyway.

In my experience, while this _can_ happen, it does not always reliably do so. Having the option to explicitly change the contraction dimensions just makes it a lot easier and more reliable.
- hawkinsp commented on 2020-10-07T15:48:32Z: `jax.make_jaxpr` shows JAX IR before optimization, so I wouldn't expect it to have any transpose/dot folding.

If you want to view the optimized XLA HLO (note: internal API use):

```
>>> print(jax.lib.xla_bridge.get_backend().compile(jax.xla_computation(my_matmul)(a, b)).hlo_modules()[0].to_string())
HloModule xla_computation__lambda___6.14

ENTRY %xla_computation__lambda___6.14 (parameter.1: f32[7,2,3], parameter.2: f32[7,2,3]) -> (f32[7,2,2]) {
  %parameter.1 = f32[7,2,3]{2,1,0} parameter(0)
  %parameter.2 = f32[7,2,3]{2,1,0} parameter(1)
  %transpose = f32[7,3,2]{2,1,0} transpose(f32[7,2,3]{2,1,0} %parameter.2), dimensions={0,2,1}, metadata={op_type="transpose" op_name="xla_computation(<lambda>)/jit(<lambda>)/transpose[ permutation=(0, 2, 1) ]" source_file="<ipython-input-44-e6e04a279036>" source_line=3}
  %dot = f32[7,2,2]{2,1,0} dot(f32[7,2,3]{2,1,0} %parameter.1, f32[7,3,2]{2,1,0} %transpose), lhs_batch_dims={0}, lhs_contracting_dims={2}, rhs_batch_dims={0}, rhs_contracting_dims={1}, metadata={op_type="dot_general" op_name="xla_computation(<lambda>)/jit(<lambda>)/dot_general[ dimension_numbers=(((2,), (1,)), ((0,), (0,)))\n                                                     precision=None ]" source_file="<ipython-input-44-e6e04a279036>" source_line=3}
  ROOT %tuple.13 = (f32[7,2,2]{2,1,0}) tuple(f32[7,2,2]{2,1,0} %dot)
}
```

In this case you are right: XLA's CPU backend has not chosen to fuse the transpose with the `dot`. I filed a bug with the XLA folks, given that the underlying kernel does support fused transposes.

(By contrast, on TPU, XLA will fuse these operations, particularly if the matrices are larger.)

I'd also agree with @shoyer that we want to be cautious about extending NumPy's API. It's possible we could change `einsum` to try even harder to avoid adding a transpose to the output.
- antoniojkim commented on 2020-10-07T16:09:04Z: @hawkinsp That is fine. If the API change is a big deal, I'll just change the contraction dimensions explicitly in my code. I look forward to this being resolved internally in the future so that I don't have to do it manually. Thanks for your timely responses!
- hawkinsp commented on 2020-10-08T13:24:42Z: The XLA folks noted that this optimization appears not to be implemented for batched matrix multiplications at the moment. But it will happen for unbatched ones. e.g., if I remove the batch dim from your example, I get:
```
HloModule xla_computation__lambda___2.14

ENTRY %xla_computation__lambda___2.14 (parameter.1: f32[2,3], parameter.2: f32[2,3]) -> (f32[2,2]) {
  %parameter.1 = f32[2,3]{1,0} parameter(0)
  %parameter.2 = f32[2,3]{1,0} parameter(1)
  %dot.1 = f32[2,2]{1,0} dot(f32[2,3]{1,0} %parameter.1, f32[2,3]{1,0} %parameter.2), lhs_contracting_dims={1}, rhs_contracting_dims={1}, metadata={op_type="dot_general" op_name="xla_computation(<lambda>)/jit(<lambda>)/dot_general[ dimension_numbers=(((1,), (0,)), ((), ()))\n                                                     precision=None ]" source_file="<ipython-input-8-81b4a98a625c>" source_line=3}
  ROOT %tuple.13 = (f32[2,2]{1,0}) tuple(f32[2,2]{1,0} %dot.1)
}
```
- antoniojkim commented on 2020-10-08T13:39:09Z: @hawkinsp I see. Is there a ticket for getting it implemented for batched matrix multiplications? Especially when it comes to high-performance ML, having fast batched operations is ideal. While it is possible to implement this functionality manually by explicitly calling `lax.dot_general` and specifying the contraction dimensions, it would be nice if it was conveniently exposed in a higher level numpy-like function.
- hawkinsp commented on 2020-10-08T13:59:48Z: I've reported a bug and hopefully they will fix it. The relevant XLA compilation pass is here:

https://cs.opensource.google/tensorflow/tensorflow/+/master:tensorflow/compiler/xla/service/transpose_folding.h?q=transpose_folding.h&ss=tensorflow%2Ftensorflow

Note we weren't ruling out exposing transposed matmuls, just expressing caution about extending NumPy's API and expressing a desire to use composition where possible.

- hawkinsp commented on 2020-10-08T19:01:19Z: https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/commit/19db1548e8b6b614377dbc314207eab92652ae94 fixed the XLA transpose folding and #4507 incorporates it into jaxlib. (We'll need to make a jaxlib release or you'll need to build from source to see it, though.)
- antoniojkim commented on 2020-10-09T00:03:25Z: @hawkinsp Awesome! I'll be sure to try it out. Do you know when the next jaxlib release is going to be?
- hawkinsp commented on 2020-10-12T19:44:01Z: We're going to try to make a jaxlib release in the next few days.

Comments:
- gehring commented on 2020-08-11T18:57:20Z: @shoyer Do you have any recommendations for how I can improve this implementation of GMRES? There seems to be some convergence issues when dealing with float32. I'm happy to rework whatever is necessary if you have some pointers to papers or pseudocode I could follow.
- alewis commented on 2020-08-19T17:56:09Z: We have just recently completed a Jax GMRES implementation in https://github.com/google/TensorNetwork, if you guys would like to synchronize. It should be a bit more efficient than this one because it builds the QR decomposition iteratively along with the Krylov space, instead of in one shot at the end; this allows it to terminate early when necessary. We didn't write it with differentiability in mind, however.
- gehring commented on 2020-08-19T18:06:44Z: Awesome! I'd like to get some confirmation from the JAX devs that they are still interested in adding GMRES before spending more time on this, but if they are, I'm happy to bring in TensorNetwork's iterative QR decomposition and see how it does. As for differentiability, that shouldn't be an issue since we define the differentiation rules using the implicit function theorem, e.g., `jax.lax.custom_linear_solve`.

@alewis How is the numerical stability when using float32? I've been having issues getting my implementation working reliably in float32 and I'm curious to hear if the implementation in TensorNetwork behaves any better.
- shoyer commented on 2020-08-19T19:10:29Z: I'm definitely quite supportive of this effort to add GMRES into JAX. Iterative linear solvers are a key building block for scientific computing, and the current CG solver does not suffice due to the restrictions it requires on the types of linear operators.
- alewis commented on 2020-08-20T16:24:01Z: As far as I can tell ours works fine in float32. @gehring @shoyer should we gvc to coordinate on this at some point?
- alewis commented on 2020-08-20T16:27:11Z: The implementation in question is in https://github.com/google/TensorNetwork/pull/767 if you'd like to take a look. It begins at line 531 of tensornetwork/backends/jax/jitted_functions.py
- gehring commented on 2020-08-20T16:59:32Z: @alewis Thanks for the pointer! One thing to decide is how much should the implementation favor GPU friendly features over CPU friendly features. For instance, @shoyer found some significant speed ups going from modified Gram-Schmidt to classical Gram-Schmidt (which is what is used in this PR currently) since it can get away with fewer more vectorized operations.

>  @gehring @shoyer should we gvc to coordinate on this at some point?

I'm happy to chat sometime next week.
- shoyer commented on 2020-08-20T17:48:37Z: > @alewis Thanks for the pointer! One thing to decide is how much should the implementation favor GPU friendly features over CPU friendly features. For instance, @shoyer found some significant speed ups going from modified Gram-Schmidt to classical Gram-Schmidt (which is what is used in this PR currently) since it can get away with fewer more vectorized operations.

Given the use-cases for JAX, I would default to accelerator friendly implementations. But I'm also happy to have multiple implementations.
- alewis commented on 2020-08-20T18:46:19Z: Our PR uses modified (we call it 'stabilized') Gram-Schmidt. That being said, in realistic use-cases the operations upon the Krylov subspace are a small expense relative to the cost of the matvec evaluation, since this subspace will normally have much smaller dimension than the linear operator. Therefore in practical situations the CPU vs GPU friendliness reduces to that of the matvec.
- alewis commented on 2020-08-20T18:48:31Z: One thing that *does* matter a lot is whether or not the matvec is Jitted. Our implementation Jits the matvec once, and then caches the result in a variable declared at the module level; otherwise the matvec gets repeatedly traced every time it is called (i.e. during the Arnoldi iterations). This has a huge performance benefit in TensorNetwork but might not be viable in Jax itself.

@mganahl @Thenerdstation 
- chaserileyroberts commented on 2020-08-20T19:00:23Z: I think within the jax's library you can assume the function being passed in is already jitted, whereas in TN we can't easily make that assumption.
- shoyer commented on 2020-08-20T19:09:35Z: Within JAX, I think the only case we really need to worry about for performance is if the _entire_ call to GMRES is jitted.
- alewis commented on 2020-08-24T16:39:32Z: @gehring Any chance we can chat today (for example)?
- gehring commented on 2020-08-24T16:45:04Z: @alewis Sure! Can you send me an email so we can work out the details? You should be able to find my email by searching my name (see gehring/fax). 
- shoyer commented on 2020-11-28T08:24:31Z: Merged in #4832

<img width="400" alt="image" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19637339/85454331-b97d3800-b594-11ea-85a6-b68ace65a859.png">

Thanks @shoyer for spotting this link issue in Sphinx/reStructuredText. Another JAX notebook here had a similar issue that I spotted recently and fixed by attaching the hyperlinks to plain words (see https://github.com/google/jax/pull/3502/commits/86fcc77710a9cae27d9caa536709b09a8c7efce4 and https://github.com/google/jax/pull/3501/commits/f351da772435cdd553ecc02921383aef66b2001f)

In the Quickstart, I use the following format for functions and methods that have API doc links:

```
[pmap()](https://jax.readthedocs.io/...)
```

which will look like plain text with round brackets: e.g. [ohFunctionMyFunction()](www.google.com) — notice the lack of back ticks. They causes the original issues (see below).

On the other hand, they're blue and not red.

_More background:_

For external links, Sphinx follows this rule, which already uses back ticks:

```
This is the preferred way in RTD/Sphinx:

`pmap <https://jax.readthedocs.io/...>`_
```

Meanwhile, this clashes with standard Markdown, which Sphinx supports, just not fully:

```Markdown

This is normal Markdown outside of RTD/Sphinx:

[`pmap`](https://jax.readthedocs.io/...)
```

(See: https://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/master/usage/restructuredtext/basics.html#external-links)

So, adding more back ticks around the name of functions that we want to link the API docs to only breaks the sequence/links/everything else.

For everything else that doesn't require external links, we leave them as before: `jax.random`, `vmap`, `@jit` (vs @[jit]()), etc.

- 8bitmp3 commented on 2020-07-06T13:39:22Z: Another suggestion @skye @shoyer 

- What if we don't let the Sphinx plugin execute the notebooks when building the docs site? 
- Instead, we run the cells in Colab from top to bottom before saving the notebooks while keeping all the cell output.
- Sphinx's Jupyter notebook plugin - `nbsphinx` - would render only the input and the output (which has been pre-run in Colab in advance).

I got this idea because in MkDocs (a Sphinx alternative) there's a plugin called MkDocs Jupyter that allows to:
> view them without having to pre-run them (you simply state execute: False in a YAML).

And in Sphinx - where you use the `nbsphinx` plugin for Jupyter - there's an option to [never execute](https://nbsphinx.readthedocs.io/en/0.7.1/never-execute.html).

So, in `conf.py` you change the settings to `never` from `always`:

```
...
# Execute notebooks before conversion: 'always', 'never', 'auto' (default)
# We execute all notebooks, exclude the slow ones using 'exclude_patterns'
nbsphinx_execute = 'never'
...
```

For example, this is the Auto-Batching Log-Densities Example notebook that shows which cells were run by the original author before saving the notebook:

<img width="900" alt="image" src="https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19637339/86598972-e1599c00-bf95-11ea-9820-07904d3e42b7.png">
